That is almost four times the original projections. The proposal in the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005 to raise the thresholds to the original levels is anticipated to bring that projected cost back down to $1.15 billion, but this is a projected cost for only the next four years, and it is still more than double the cost forecast by the government in March last year, when the safety net was introduced. Yet this still means that one million fewer people will qualify for the safety net. How on earth is the government going to keep trying to restick this Medicare safety net bandaid over the balong term, when the bandaid itself started falling off as soon as it was stuck on? How many more people will fail to qualify for support when they need it, and who will those middle- qualify when they do not? An examination of the electorate-byelectorate figures shows a growing bias to well-off seats anyway. Let us look at some comments made from various sources over the last little while. As the Minister for Health and Ageing said: From 1 January 2006, the extended Medicare safety net thresholds will increase from $306.90 to $500 for concession card holders and families in receipt of family tax benefit part A, and from $716.10 to $1,000 for all other families and individuals. The current thresholds will continue to apply to all families and individuals for the current calendar year. The Bills Digest for this legislation says: ... the reason expenditure on the Safety Net has blown out ... is a result of the Safety Net's ture, whereby Safety Net benefits are not tied to any price signals-that is, they are uncapped and effectively unregulated. As the member for Hotham said in this second reading debate: If Medicare were functioning properly and if it were funded properly, there would not be a need for a safety net. Therein lie the exact reasons why we have this gradually increasing unfairness built into the safety net process. Any benefit the safety net might offer is entirely contingent on the amount charged by the practitioner. It is not tied to any price control whatsoever, unlike the normal Medicare rebate, which is hooked to the Medicare schedule fee. As I have continued to point out for a number of years, consumers-but not the government-can see that medical fees will continue to rise with the unlimited expenditure that comes with the Medicare safety net. Raising the threshold only begs the question about who exactly is going to benefit-the medical practitioners charging way beyond normal prices and their well-heeled patients? Certainly not the sick and poor, who can ill afford to access these specialists in the first place, let alone afford to spend enough on their health care to reach that new threshold. The government has no problem with asking the taxpayer to fork out at least $1.65 billion to support those who have been able to afford to reach the higher threshold, because it is not explicitly obvious to the taxpayer. But, if I dare to suggest that we attend to the core of the problem by properly investing in a universal health system for the long term, both sides of the House bury their collective heads in the sand. I have long argued that both the schedule fee and the Medicare rebate to doctors, and the schedule fee on which the rebate is calculated, should be raised to realistically reflect the cost and worth of medical consultations for GPs in strucparticular. Certainly, in previous years, the AMA and the Productivity Commission have recognised this-and perhaps I would take the Productivity Commission's assessment before the AMA's. They have said a $50 standard consultation fee is far closer to the mark than the current schedule fee, which stands at $30. Most of the electorate know that this is an acceptable thing to do and are prepared to pay for a fairer system, as long as their money, through Medicare and through their taxes, is going into the Medicare bucket. But this bill ensures that Australia's money is instead, by stealth, redirected not into a universal health care system but into the pockets of higher fee charging medical practitioners. Poorer, often more elderly, constituents are left to struggle with not only their illness and disease but the inability to afford the specialist care they badly need. Often they cannot afford even to make the journey to the medical help and support that they so desperately need. This is tackling health care from the wrong end and building inflationary pressure into health care costs, to the disadvantage of the needy. I cannot support this legislation. It will be very interesting to see what Senator Joyce and Senator Fielding, in that other place, think of the ‘family friendly' elements of this piece of legislation. In an overview of the figures that have been put out about the safety net provisions-I do not have them with me-it is interesting to see the electorates that are showing a marked increase in access to this benefit. They are certainly not those rural and regional electorates where the poorer recipients of health care and those who are in desperate need of that support live. On that note, I reiterate that nothing in this suggests to me that there is any plan by this government to properly protect those most vulnerable in our society, who demand and deserve the medical protection that they certainly need. They will be left without it, and this is amounts. skewed entirely in favour of those at the other end of the spectrum who can certainly afford to pay more for their health care.

Speaker: Ms HOARE
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Who would expect the Howard government to be any different from previous conservative governments? Labor's Whitlam government in the 1970s introduced much needed free hospital treatment and the Medibank rebate system. The Fraser Liberal government took those services away, only for them to be replaced with Medicare by the Hawke Labor government in 1984. Since the 1970s the conservatives have never really been supportive of Australians receiving free medical treatment. This was apparent when the Howard government suggested changes to Medicare to make it look like the American twotiered system and named the package, very inappropriately, A Fairer Medicare. These changes were only prevented because the coalition did not have the numbers in the Senate to pass the legislation. If the proposed A Fairer Medicare legislation had been allowed to pass it would have meant the end of Medicare as we know it. However, with the assistance of Independent senators and a lowering of the initially proposed thresholds of $500 for concession card holders and other low-income earners and $1,000 for all other individuals and families to $300 and $700 retrospectively, the Minister for Health and Ageing, Mr Abbott, was able to get support for the MedicarePlus reforms introduced in March 2004. Even prior to these reforms being legislated, there were grave concerns that the cost of the safety net provision would blow out. If only the minister had listened to the health experts. If he had taken the time to listen, he would not now be going back on his election promises. Instead of listening, Minister Abbott gave his now famous ‘rock solid, ironclad' guarantee for safety net threshold Why did the minister and this government fail to listen to advice given by health experts regarding the risks associated with the safety net? It was clear to these health experts that the proposed package contained serious design flaws which would be inflationary and would lead to the blow-out of costs for the safety net component of the package. Only one conclusion can be drawn from the government's inability to listen to the experts: the government has no real commitment to providing a long-term solution to a real issue. The real issue that Australians are constantly being faced with is the escalating outof-pocket expenses associated with seeing a specialist or with the use of diagnostic technology. The Howard government invented the safety net as an advertising stunt to win votes. The coalition government was well aware of the concerns many Australians had with Australia's health system prior to the election. As previously pointed out, coalition governments do not have a good track record in providing Australians with affordable and adequate health services; on the contrary, coalition governments have a proven track record in dismantling and dissolving public health services. While some might say that this is history, the Howard government has done nothing concrete to prove any commitment to providing all Australians with long-term, sustainable and affordable health services. The Medicare safety net provided only a shortterm solution to a long-term problem. This was evident during the election campaign, but Minister Abbott and Prime Minister Howard chose to ignore what they were being told. Even their own Treasury tried to warn the government that the cost of the Medicare safety net would be more than double their original forecasts for the 200405 financial year. This forecast was made in the pre-election fiscal and economic outlook of September 2004 published by the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance and Administration. So a month before the federal election the government had formally been advised by its Treasury that the total cost of the safety net would blow out greatly. Forecasts were given that the blow-out would be more than double the original projections, but did Minister Abbott listen? Apparently not. This is why Australians are now faced with the real possibility of an increase in the safety net thresholds. It is completely unacceptable. This election promise was instrumental to the coalition parties winning government. Without this policy, which we can now assume was a scam, the Howard government's success may not have been achieved. Why did the minister choose to ignore the Treasury's advice? Was it because if he had changed his proposed policy the attractiveness of it would have been lost? Was it because the government's credibility would have been questioned? Yes, of course the attractiveness of this proposal would have been lost and, yes, of course the government's credibility would have been destroyed. So Minister Abbott chose to ignore the flaws in his policy and mislead electors. He led the Australian public to believe that the Medicare safety net proposal was a bona fide election promise and that if the coalition government was re-elected it would enact that policy. The only problem was that electors believed from the coalition's advertising that the safety net thresholds would be in place for a considerable time. With the safety net proposal being a part of the coalition's MedicarePlus policy, the Howard-Abbott team invaded electors' emotions, suggesting that if re-elected they would provide a better health system for all Australians. As all Australians would remember, the coalition government embarked on a massive advertising campaign to tell us how much better off we would be if the coalition won government. The advertising campaign to promote MedicarePlus was forced into every household and householders received the MedicarePlus booklet in their mailboxes. It was nearly impossible for families and individuals to avoid the onslaught of television, radio and newspaper advertising used as part of the federal government's propaganda campaign to win votes at the upcoming election. The government advertising that was intended to persuade and convince Australians to vote for the coalition worked. Many Australians voted for the coalition believing that all aspects of MedicarePlus were fully costed and affordable. Little did voters know that the federal government was receiving advice from Treasury that the policy was flawed. I suppose if the federal government had given the Australian electors this relevant information it may have ruined its chances of being re-elected. Would that have been the price of informing the general public of the true facts? Surely Australian voters had the right to all the information, not just the propaganda being distributed by the federal government. Less than six months following the election of the coalition, Minister Abbott introduced the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005. There is no surprise that, in this bill, he suggests an increase in the safety net thresholds. And it is not a surprise that the suggested increases are the same as the government tried to get through the Senate previously. They were unsuccessful then but, with a majority in the Senate, they are certain to get the increases through now. From 1 January 2006 the Medicare safety net thresholds will increase from $300 to $500 for concession card holders and low-income families and from $700 to $1,000 for all remaining Australians. Minister Abbott is now acknowledging his estimates need to be revised. However, this is a bit late. He knew when his government initially proposed the safety net idea that it was not feasible to reduce the threshold, but he did so just to get it through the Senate. In minister's second reading speech on the Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Safety-nets) Bill 2005, he told us that an overriding concern for the government was the long-term sustainability of the safety net, yet he failed to inform the general public of these concerns. Through the federal government's advertising campaign the minister pushed the lower amounts as bait. Minister Abbott knew prior to the federal election that he could not sustain the $300 and $700 thresholds, yet he led the Australian public to believe he could. Now the minister wants the Australian public to believe that the government had not foreseen the blow-out in the costs of this tiative. I challenge Minister Abbott on this matter. He and his government were fully aware, when introducing this proposal in 2003, of the full costs associated with the introduction of the safety net. He knew this because he was aware that, to be economically responsible, the safety net thresholds would have to be $500 for concession card holders and low-income earners and $1,000 for all other Australians. The minister received relevant advice from Treasury during the federal election campaign that the costs of the Medicare safety net would be more than double the forecast for the 2004-05 financial year. But during the election campaign he gave his famous rock-solid, ironclad guarantee. There was nothing rock-solid or ironclad about his guarantee at all. This guarantee has now become a patina of respectability covering a vacuum of inconsequentiality. Minister Abbott also stated during his second reading speech on the bill that more people than expected qualified for the safety net benefits and that the out-of-pocket medical expenses turned out to be considerably higher. Surely the minister had access to figures which outlined those eligible for assisthe tance under the safety net provision. The federal government would have available to them the current statistics and forecasts. The Australian people deserve better than this from their federal government. Minister Abbott should come clean and tell the Australian people the true facts regarding the Medicare safety net. The Australian people should have been told that from the beginning the federal government was aware that the safety net thresholds, which the Senate accepted, were too low. The federal government was aware that there would be a blowout in estimated costs. The federal government was fully aware that it would have to increase the Medicare safety net thresholds ini- to ensure that the blow-out would not continue. If the federal government was fully aware of all these facts, why wasn't the Australian public? Also in his second reading of the bill, the minister would like to blame some specialties for shifting charges onto Medicare outof-hospital items so that their patients could claim the safety net entitlements. He is quick to blame others for the faults of his government's legislation. Why was the government's legislation able to be penetrated by specialties? Surely the government should have been able to ensure there were no loopholes in their legislation to enable this. The minister should be strong enough to take full responsibility for the failures of his government's Medicare safety net legislation and not try to blame others for the blow-out. The failure of the Medicare safety net legislation rests plainly on the shoulders of the federal government and the minister in particular. What will happen as a result of the federal government's decision to increase the safety net thresholds? One million Australians will miss out on higher Medicare benefits. That is one million Australians who will be disadvantaged through the federal government's mishandling of the safety net facts. According to an article printed in the Age newspaper: Health Department officials revealed in Senate estimates hearings ... that under the old scheme, 2.5 million patients would have reached the safety net next year. But after the Government broke a key election promise by raising the thresholds at which the safety net kicks in, the estimate has plummeted to 1.5 million. This means there will be two-and-a-half times as many losers as the Government suggested when it announced the cuts in April. These losers, the one million Australians who will miss out on assistance from the safety net policy changes, will be those who live in rural Australia, those who live in regional towns, people who live in outer metropolitan areas and people who live in the inner city areas associated with low incomes. Constituents in my electorate, Charlton, will miss out. Many in my community can illafford to be disadvantaged by the proposed changes in these thresholds. Although I am appalled that the federal government is even contemplating the increase in the safety net threshold, I am even more appalled that the Medicare safety net is skewed towards the upper income end of Australian society. Through the ABS survey of household expenditure, it was revealed that the higher a person's income the more likely they are to have a high expenditure on health. This means that there are people with discretionary income, who can sustain high out-ofpocket costs, who will have the treatment and, therefore, are more likely to add up the out-of-pocket costs, which will enable them to access the safety net. While the minister and the government would like to lead Australians to the conclusion that the most in need benefit from the safety net, this is not the case. As proven with past and present coalition governments, there is no desire to provide all Australians with adequate health services. When will a coalition government provide adequate health services to all Australians regardless of income? Never. I take this opportunity to challenge the government and Minister Abbott, who is responsible for health, to address the health issues facing Australia. It is the government's job to improve health services in Australia. It is not their job to move the goalposts to disadvantage those on low incomes. While Labor did not support the safety net policy, we do expect Minister Abbott to keep his word. The government spent an enormous amount of taxpayers' money spreading their propaganda regarding the safety net and the amounts that would be applied. The government gave a pledge to the Australian people. It should now keep that pledge. ‘Changes take the knife to Medicare safety-net benefits' and ‘Budget measures mean that out-of-hospital and drug costs will rise' were the headlines in the Australian Financial Review of 14 May 2005, following the last federal budget. The article said: For 29-year-old Andrea Holden, cuts to major health entitlements in this week's federal budget mean her recent knee operation just got a lot more expensive. Health benefits were about the only thing to be cut in a generous first budget for the Howard government's fourth term. And the government made sure the bad news about restrictions to the Medicare safety netunder which the government pays 80 per cent of a patient's out-of-hospital costs once they've spent a certain amount-wasn't around to muddy the news of the tax cuts, announcing it a few weeks before the budget. And while the government is offering a tax-cut calculator for the punters to work out how the largesse applies to them, there is no similar health-cut calculator. That's because if you get sick, like Andrea, the government suddenly looks a whole lot less generous. According to Catholic Health Australia chief executive Francis Sullivan, the government, like a reverse Robin Hood, is taking from the sick to give tax cuts to the healthy and wealthy. … … … HeMr Sullivansays Australia is moving to a situation where “we say ‘well, it's just bad luck if you're sick, you just have to pay more'.” What if you are not in a position to pay for health services? Do you just go without? Does the government really care? If the government really cared about Australians it would not have introduced the MedicarePlus policy, which included the Medicare safety net provision. It would have introduced policies such as the ones proposed by Labor. Labor's policies would have provided equal health services for all Australians, not just the rich. Labor is prepared to assist people to avoid high out-of-pocket costs when they need specialist care or access to diagnostic technology by making that care and technology available out of the public hospital system. Labor's hospitals package offered Australians specialist care and access to diagnostic technologies in public hospitals, without the obligation of paying a gap. This is what the Australian public want and deserve. Why can't the government deliver appropriate heath services to all Australians? Why can't it handle its finances so that all Australians can be entitled to better health services? Even the Treasurer, Peter Costello, has warned that Australians will have to get used to paying a bigger share of their health care costs to fireproof government spending. This just proves that the government has no intention of caring for all Australians, just the ones who can afford to look after themselves. So the truth of the matter is that the Howard coalition government is no different from previous conservative governments. The government has no real desire to improve Medicare. Its only intentions are to dismantle it, as previous coalition governments have done. The Howard government misled the general public by its propaganda during the federal election campaign, and continues to do so by not admitting to what it has in store for Medicare and the millions of average Australians who rely on it for basic medical needs.

Speaker: Ms CORCORAN
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Isaacs) (1.17 pm)The purpose of the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005 is to increase the level at which patients can access the Medicare safety net. Right now the safety net can be accessed once a family or individual spends $716.10 in a calendar year, or $306.90 for a family or individual holding a Commonwealth concession card or who is eligible for family tax benefit A. The safety net reimburses 80 per cent of all out-ofpocket expenses met by a patient once the threshold has been reached. The bill is notorious now because it breaks the rock solid, ironclad guarantee that the Minister for Health and Ageing gave the electorate in the last election campaign period. That guarantee was that the threshold for the safety net would not be increased. When the safety net was first introduced in November 2003 the government's proposal was for thresholds of $500 and $1,000. The initial cost of this measure was estimated to be $266.3 million for the four years 2003-04 to 2006-07. In order to get this legislation through the Senate the government negotiated with individual senators, and the thresholds were eventually reduced to $300 and $500. The revised cost of this was set at $440 million. This was in March 2004. This legislation before us now is to restore the thresholds to the original proposals of $500 and $300, effective from 1 January 2006. There are a number of issues worth thinking about in relation to the bill, and these are the initial reason for the safety the sense or otherwise of the principle of the safety net as a public policy, the consequences of the safety net to date, the ability of the safety net to assist those struggling to meet medical costs and the behaviour of the government and the minister in managing this policy. So why was the safety net introduced in the first place? The original legislation has be seen in the perspective of the time it was introduced. We are talking about 2003, with an election looming within 12 months. One of the consistent themes of a restless electorate was access to affordable health care. Medicare was seen as being not as useful as it once was in delivering affordable health care, because bulk-billing rates were decreasing rapidly-that is, the number of doctors prepared to offer bulk-billing to their patients. From the time that Medicare was introduced in 1983, bulk-billing grew steadily. It reached around 80 per cent in 1996. From there, it turned south, and by 2003-04 the rate had dropped to an average of 68 per cent across Australia. In Isaacs bulk-billing was 83 per cent in 1996, and this had dropped to around 70 per cent by 2003-04. I want to make it clear that I do not altogether blame the doctors for moving away from bulkbilling. A doctor's practice has many expenses and needs to operate on a sound financial footing. After all, doctors and their staff are entitled to make a reasonable living, as is everybody else. The rebates being paid under Medicare had not moved for a long time, and many doctors discovered that they were falling behind financially. Anecdotal evidence suggests that the bigger practices were doing better than the smaller ones or the one-person practices. At the same time that bulk-billing was declining, the gap that patients were asked to net, pay when they visited their non bulk-billing doctor was growing. Many doctors were asking patients to pay their fees up front, and this was putting enormous stress on many people. We know that mothers with a couple of sick kids would take one child to the doctor, thus incurring only one doctor's bill, get a prescription for that one child, have it filled and then share the medicine around the rest to of the family. In that way they were doing nobody any good at all. I recently spoke to a cancer patient who approached me while I was doing a mobile office. She told me that she had her condition under control but needed to see her specialist from time to time when the pain got bad. She said that things changed for her when the specialist stopped bulk-billing and introduced an up-front fee. Now, if the pain arrives in a week when dollars are short, my constituent does not get her pain relief-she cannot afford to. She was getting her health care on the basis of her financial situation and not on the basis of her health needs. This is the sort of thing that was being heard right across Australia, and the government recognised that it at least had to be seen to be doing something. It would have been better, though, if it had actually done something. So the government introduced the safety net. The government hoped that, if a patient or family could see that their doctor's bills would not grow beyond a certain level, they would be reassured and stop agitating for the issues facing Medicare to be addressed properly. How does the safety net stand the test sensible public policy? It does not. This point was made at the time by the opposition and by many in the health sector. The argument was, and is, that this measure simply writes a blank cheque on health costs whilst not assisting many of those who are finding it hard to afford decent health care. The financial constraint on Medicare is the regulation of how much a doctor is paid-that is, the rebate amount. Whilst there is criticism of the current level of the rebate, that does not take away its function as a regulating device. The safety net has no such regulation; it is unregulated and uncapped-in other words, a blank cheque. The scheme pays 80 per cent of an unregulated fee for an indefinite time. There is nothing stopping unscrupulous doctors from noting that a patient is on the safety net and hiking up fees. We have had anecdotal evidence of some doctors rearranging the fee structure for managing pregnancy so that most of the fee now applies to care outside the hospital, which qualifies it for safety net purposes. The scheme was always going to be hard to control, and that is exactly what has happened. It is intriguing that a government which prides itself on good economic management could introduce a runaway train such as this scheme. What happened once the scheme got under way? Surprise, surprise-the costs went through the roof. The scheme's original estimated cost, with the new thresholds, was $440 million for the three years from 2005-06 to 2007-08. This was the estimate in March 2004, as it was introduced. Twelve months later, in April 2005, the estimate had moved to $1.4 billion for the same period-over three times the original amount. The estimate for the four years to 2008-09 was $1.6 billion. Clearly, the runaway train was gathering speed at an alarming rate. This blow-out was entirely predictable. of But, despite all the money flowing around the system, the scheme is still not helping those who are struggling to meet their doctors bills. If the young mother or the constituent with cancer about whom I spoke earlier have to look in their purses before ringing the doctor, this scheme does not help. It will help once they reach the threshold but, until that point, they are still in trouble. If the cash is not there now, no amount of promises of future relief will help. A person on a tight budget is still left looking in their purse first and ringing the doctor second. This type of assistance is starting to become a pattern. Just recently, we saw a bill to introduce tax rebates for child care. That arrangement will give relief to a family long after they have paid the child-care bills, but it does not do a single thing to help a family who cannot afford child care today. The safety net scheme is the same. It is fine in the long term but does not do a thing to help those who are facing immediate financial difficulties. I do not know whether the government genuinely cannot see this point or just does not care. A family on a tight budget is like a business on a tight budget: cash flow is a real issue every day. I challenge the minister to show me how the safety net can help those whom I have spoken about. It is worth noting some interesting stats which show very clearly that this scheme is not helping those in real financial need. An analysis of how much has been spent on the safety net, and where it has been spent, shows that the electorate with the highest average income, Bradfield in New South Wales, had received the highest amount of safety net rebate as at September 2004. Bradfield has an average income of $1,759 per household and received $911,000 in rebates. Isaacs, with an average income of only half that amount, or $959 per household, received just over $226,000-a quarter of the amount the residents of Bradfield received. The analysis shows a marked correlation between income and the amount of rebate received. This means that those with a higher disposable income are taking advantage of the safety net-and why wouldn't they-whilst those with much lower incomes are not able to do so. Of the 150 electorates in Australia, 20 received more than $400,000. Only two of those electorates had an average income of under $1,000 per week-the rest of them have an average income of over $1,200 per week. Twenty-two electorates received less than $100,000. Four of these electorates have an average income of over $1,000 per week-the rest of them are well below that figure. Finally, I want to talk about how the government and the Minister for Health and Ageing have managed the cost blow-out in this scheme. In a real sense, the entirely dictable cost blow-out has not been managed at all-as I said earlier, it is a blank cheque. The changes proposed by this bill simply raise the bar a bit, before patients can access the safety net. Those who spend more will eventually benefit-provided that they can afford to seek the medical treatment they need in the first place. The question I really want to address, though, is the political management-or mismanagement-of this issue. It was entirely predictable that the cost of this scheme would blow out. If the minister was not able to work this out for himself, plenty of people around him were telling him so, including many on this side of the House. Information which came out in Senate estimates showed that the minister would have been briefed by the department as early as July 2004 on the fact that there were serious financial problems with the safety net. The minister did not take any action. Throughout the 2004 election campaign, the minister stuck to his story that the safety net would not be altered. He gave the now infamous rock solid, ironclad guarantee that it would stay as it was. As with so many other matters the government deals with, it is difficult to work out whether the minister did not understand the implications of the legislation he was developing or he understood precisely what he was doing and went ahead with it anyway to try to avoid the flak on the growing problem of medical costs in the electorate, in an election year. From a political point of view, there are two aspects of the management of this problem: firstly, the delayed admission that a problem existed and, secondly, the denial that the system would be altered. The safety net scheme came into effect in March 2004. Very quickly it became clear that it was going to be a problem. Within the first three months of operation of the safety net, 500,000 individuals and families had preregistered for it. Actual expenditure on the safety net rebates exceeded the estimated expenditure by 40 per cent. This reached 60 per cent by July 2004 and 70 per cent by August 2004. By then, of course, an election was looming, and it was called at the end of August. During the election campaign period, the Charter of Budget Honesty process threw up costings which showed that the safety net was then costing almost double original estimates. Let me give you just one example of the Treasurer and the Minister for Health and Ageing each guaranteeing that the safety net would remain as it was before the election, despite the cost blow-out. We have the famous words that the health minister used on 6 September 2004 in response to repeated questions from a journalist about the safety net. The journalist asked: Will this Government commit to keeping the Medicare-plus-safety-net as it is now in place after the election? Minister: Yes. Journalist: That's a cast-iron commitment? Minister: Cast-iron commitment. Absolutely. Journalist: 80 per cent of out-of-pocket expenses rebatable over $300, over $700? Minister: That is an absolutely rock solid, iron-clad mitment. Earlier, on 2 September, the Treasurer, at a doorstop interview, said: The parameters of the Medicare safety net will not change. Very clearly, the government was telling us that the Medicare safety net would not change. During that election campaign, the Prime Minister was always ready to scoff at Labor's health policies. At the same time, he sang the praises of the safety net and reinforced his commitment not to cut it. In a press conference in Sydney on 8 October, the Prime Minister made it clear that he was aware of some doctors exploiting the scheme and said that he would deal with that problem. He acknowledged, in a backhanded way, the problems of the uncontrolled nature of the safety net. He tried to defend this by saying that there was no cap on the availability of Medicare services either. But he missed the point: there is a cap on the rebate available for a service under Medicare because the rebate is linked to an approved fee for each service. This is not the case for the rebate available under the safety net arrangements; it is essentially a blank cheque. In summary, the safety net scheme does not help people get affordable health care when they need it. It is a cruel deal for those who believed the government in the election campaign period when they talked about the rock solid, ironclad guarantee. The government were dishonest about the scheme during 2004 and leading up to the election campaign. This is not good policy. It is a blank cheque. And it does not address the problem of providing affordable health care for all Australians. Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR (Corio) (1.32 pm)-The Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005 is another broken promise of the Howard government. comAfter nine long years of the Howard government being in power, we are debating in this House yet another of their broken promises. Members and the community will know that the bill that we are debating here today, relating to the Prime Minister's much vaunted Medicare safety net, is but one broken promise that the Prime Minister has made. I will recast for the House some of the other broken promises of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister said that he would never, ever introduce a GST. And he did. He betrayed the trust that was given to him by the Australian people when he went back on that commitment. If we look at what the Prime Minister's policies said on Iraq and his justification for Australia and Australian troops being committed to war, we find that there never were any weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. Yet that was what the Prime Minister gave to the Australian people as a reasoned basis for our involvement. Today in this House we have been debating Telstra bills and the sale of one of Australia's great economic assets. Those bills went through this parliament barely an hour ago. I can recall the Prime Minister telling the Australian people that he would never, ever privatise Telstra; but when he did, with T1 and T2, he still gave a commitment to the Australian people-a commitment that he broke. And here we have in the Medicare safety net legislation before us today another example of the deceit of this government. This government does not believe in cutting health spending. That is what Minister Abbott said on 16 September 2004. So I say to the House: why are we here debating this Medicare safety net legislation? On 16 September 2004 Mr Abbott said: I absolutely guarantee that the safety net as government has put it into operation will continue. I absolutely guarantee that. If anybody in the Australian community was listening then to the words of the Minister for Health and Ageing, they would be pretty frightened and disappointed with this piece of legislation. You cannot get anything stronger than an absolute guarantee. But, as we know, the absolute guarantees of the Prime Minister are worth nothing, and now we know that the absolute guarantees of the minister for health are worth nothing. You cannot get a commitment any clearer than: I absolutely guarantee that the safety net government has put it into operation will continue. I absolutely guarantee that. Any young Australian listening to this Liberal minister for health, any young Australian listening to that rock solid commitment from a politician, would assume that the politician meant it. Well, welcome to the Liberal nightmare, because when a Liberal Prime Minister makes a promise you can guarantee it is a non-core promise. And when a Liberal health minister makes an absolute guarantee you know it is a guarantee that is not worth the paper it is written on. That is why we have this legislation in the House todaybecause the minister for health and the Prime Minister have betrayed low-income earners in this country yet again. Why are we debating this bill? Is it because the minister cannot count or, worse, that the Treasurer cannot count? Perhaps that is why the Treasurer said nothing during the election campaign. Perhaps he said nothing to maximise the ability of the government to exploit the policy when it was popular and then cut it loose as soon as they were returned to the treasury bench. You cannot get anything more cynical and deceptive than a Liberal minister in this government. The minister for health gave an absolute guaranthe tee that the Medicare safety net would stick. That would be the policy that would be implemented, and there would be no changes. He said, ‘I absolutely guarantee that.' What example is this Liberal minister setting for the young people of Australia who look to the political system for some degree of truth and some degree of morality? Does the Prime Minister of this country, whose government lied to the Australian people on Iraq-with the subsequent death of thousands of innocents-and whose words mean nothing, have any conscience when it comes to these matters? When you give a guarantee as the to the Australian people, when you give a guarantee to young people in this country, when you give a guarantee to older Australians, when you give a guarantee-an absolute guarantee-then there is a reasonable expectation that you would meet it. That ought to be the underlying morality of the Australian political system: some degree of truth from the Prime Minister and some degree of truth from the minister for health. But why should we be surprised at this deceit? When has this government shown any compassion for the low-income earners in this community? Calling them ‘mate' and saying, ‘We're in there defending the little Aussie battler' is an obscenity when you put a piece of legislation like this into this House. It does not pay the bills for the lowincome earners when you put another burden on them. In my electorate of Corio, in Geelong, we have a lot of people who are on low incomes. They are not only the pensioners, or the disadvantaged, who must rely on the government for their incomes. They are the working poor. They are people who work and cannot actually afford to pay their bills. And those people have a reasonable expectation that when a minister of the Crown in a government makes a commitment then that commitment will stick. This increase will affect low-income earners as their capacity for discretionary spending will be further diminished. Senate estimates revealed that one million people who previously qualified will now miss out-one million people who were told by the Prime Minister that this was a policy that would be implemented, and no sooner had the Prime Minister been elected than he ratted on the solemn commitment. But that is not the only promise that this Prime Minister has ratted on. He is the master of the non-core promise. I come from a rural background. My father was an honourable man. If I had ever said to him, ‘Dad, I've just made you a non-core promise,' I hate to think what would have happened to me. Yet here is the Prime Minister of Australia and a government that are masters of deceit making commitments and then going back on them after an election and, in doing so, lowering standards in politics in this country. I call on the minister to direct his departand ment to reveal what proportion will be in the lower threshold and, therefore, on lower incomes and concession cards. Did not the minister state that his government does not believe in cutting health spending? Could the minister not see the gathering clouds on this blow-out or, having spent the first eration boasting at regular press briefings about the high level of registrations and successful claimants for the safety net, did he think he could somehow just avoid the inevitable? In June 2004 actual spending on the safety net was 40 per cent more than estimated. In July 2004 spending on the safety net was 60 per cent more than estimated in the budget. In June 2004 the department of finance was starting to look at the estimates, as there were indications that the program was growing more rapidly than estimated. The Herald Sun reported in 2004 that an internal HIC audit revealed evidence of changed billing practices amongst doctors to help patients reach the safety net faster. This same report showed that more than 3,000 patients in Victoria slipped into the safety net in only one month. The audit revealed a $1.4 million blow-out of the scheme in Victoria alone. In August 2004 the office of the Minister for Finance and Administration was contacted about the blow-out, and Minister Nick Minchin was subsequently briefed. This occurred prior to the caretaker period before the election. So we ask ourselves this question: ‘Why didn't the minister react in a timely and responsible manner to this blowout, as any competent minister would in these extreme circumstances?' No, it is just easier to wait until after the election and then lift the thresholds and go back on your promise. I have heard the arguments about lags in timing of these reports but, even allowing for this, by mid-July 2004 any competent minister would have acted promptly, read the signs done something. So if there was no conspiracy to deceive-as the health minister maintains-does this mean he personally had no conspiracy to deceive but rather was misguided in his blind faith that his senior cabinet colleagues would not betray him? Delusions and incompetence: that is double jeopyear's op- ardy for any minister. Sadly, this program has contributed to increased levels of health inflation. Over the 12 months to the March quarter 2005, health costs rose by 5.7 per cent, compared to the CPI in all groups which grew at 2.4 per cent. Health CPI is the second fastest growing group in the CPI basket, and only education CPI has outgrown health CPI. The cost of hospital and medical services rose by 5.8 per cent. This increase is largely attributed to increases in fees for specialist services. program has also contributed to higher specialist fees, making it harder for lower income Australians to access the specialist services they need in the first place. The government's own Medicare data has shown that there is a high correlation between incomes and levels of Medicare safety net rebates claimed. In the last five years, household spending on health has increased by over 40 per cent. This means that in 1998-99 an average family spent around $14 a week on health care and medical expenses, but in 2003-04 this weekly average increased by 46 per cent. There are very important principles at stake in the bill that we have before the House. Let me read into the Hansard the extent of the deceit of this federal minister on this issue. The transcript of an interview with Ms Ticky Fullerton on 6 September 2004 proceeds as follows: TICKY FULLERTON: Will the Government commit to keeping the Medicare-plus-safety-net as it is now in place after the election? A very clear and unequivocal question. The transcript continues: TONY ABBOTT: Yes. TICKY FULLERTON: That's a cast-iron commitment? TONY ABBOTT: Cast-iron commitment. Absolutely. It was absolutely a cast-iron commitment that Minister Abbott never intended to deliver, because they already knew, before the election, that the program was in a blow-out phase. The Howard government deceived the Australian people when the minister went on that particular program and made those statements. On 2 September 2004, Treasurer Costello said, ‘The parameters of the Medicare safety net will not change.' I notice that the member for Corangamite is in the House this afternoon. The member This for Corangamite, some would say, is an honourable man. I could not believe that the member for Corangamite would make this sort of commitment to his electors and then, in a matter of months, renege on it-rat on it. Mr MCArthur interjecting Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR-No, that would not be the style of the member for Corangamite. Then why is it the style of the minister for health, your colleague? Why is it the style of the Prime Minister? Is the member for Corangamite the only honourable person in the coalition-or does he go along with this? You can put out the voting papers there

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: The member for Corio will come back to the bill. Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR-I would really like to know what is on the piece of paper you are handing out. I hope it is not another absolute guarantee, because if it is it is not worth the paper it is written on.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Do you want me to check?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: The member for Rankin might check outside in a minute. Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR-We had a cast-iron guarantee, and this legislation now goes back on that cast-iron guarantee. The young people of Australia have a reasonable expectation that their politicians will not lie to them. So do the mums and dads with their families-they have a reasonable expectation that their government will not lie to them. The older Australians in this community and in the seat of Corio also have a reasonable expectation that they will not be lied to. Yet here in this piece of legislation we have the most cynical manipulation you will see in politics, from the Prime Minister down to the minister for health. This legislation will give effect to a broken promise. A solemn promise is broken in this legislation, and those who will pay will be the most disadvantaged in the community.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: The reason we are debating the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005 is to facilitate the breaking of a promise on the part of the Howard government. The promise that was made-an ironclad promise-was that the Medicare safety net that was put in place before the election would be retained after the election. The government was asked about the Medicare safety net's sustainability on a large number of occasions for one reason and for one reason only. That is that Labor was very concerned that this Medicare safety net that had been established in legislation by this government was not financially sustainable and, on the basis of questioning by the member for Lalor, the shadow health minister, the media took up the cause and asked on numerous occasions whether in fact this Medicare safety net would remain in place if the Howard government were re-elected. Who made the statement, ‘Truth is absolute; truth is supreme; truth is never disposable in national political life'? The answer the current Prime Minister of Australia, who made that statement 10 years ago on 25 August 1995 on the ABC radio's AM program. You would believe that having been elected to the high office of Prime Minister of Australia this man would insist that not only his conduct but the conduct of all his ministers would meet that standard-that standard being that truth is absolute, truth is supreme and truth is never disposable in national political life. Yet today, in this parliament, are debating the breaking of an ironclad promise by this government. On so many occasions the Minister for Health and Ageing, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister were asked about the sustainability of the safety net. The minister for health on 16 September last year, not long before the election, said: I absolutely guarantee that the safety net as the government has put it into operation will continue. I absolutely guarantee that. On 6 September, just 10 days before, the same minister was asked: Will this Government commit to keeping the Medicare Plus Safety Net ... in place after the election?' The minister replied yes. He was asked: That's a cast-iron commitment? And the minister said: Cast-iron commitment. Absolutely. He was asked again: 80 per cent of out-of-pocket expenses rebatable over $300, over $700? The minister said: That is an absolutely rock solid, iron-clad commitment. I say to everyone listening to this debate in the parliament: how else do you interpret a minister's statement that he has just made an absolutely rock solid, ironclad commitment? There are not two ways of interpreting that is statement. It is either a rock solid, ironclad commitment or it is not. And yet this government after the election has debased truth by arguing that no such commitment could be rock solid or ironclad because the Medicare safety net costs had blown out. This was a problem to which Labor had referred, which Labor had identified, and yet the government continued with the pretence, for one reason and for one reason only-that is, to ensure its re-election-that the Medicare we safety net was financially affordable. It was not just the minister for health. The Treasurer on 2 September last year, again in the context of the federal election campaign, said, ‘The parameters of the Medicare safety net will not change.' Yet at that very time the Minister for Finance and Administration of this government and of this country knew that the cost of the Medicare safety net was blowing out. The finance minister knew it was blowing out, the Treasurer knew it was blowing out and the health minister knew it was blowing out. Yet here they were making ironclad, rock solid guarantees that there would be no change-and today we are debating a change in those arrangements to make them more affordable. It was not just the health minister and the Treasurer-the Prime Minister got in on the act. On 12 May last year on the Neil Mitchell program on 3AW he said, ‘But it is funded in the budget.' He was referring to the Medicare safety net. He said: Now, that new safety net is funded in the budget, although it was announced several months ago but it is funded in the budget. So here is the Prime Minister saying that the Medicare safety net will stay, that it is fully funded in the budget, that it is sustainable. On 7 September, right in the middle of the federal election campaign, he said: In fact, we have a better Medicare system now than our opponents are offering because we have this new beaut safety net. So here is the Prime Minister saying we have got a ‘beaut safety net'. How beaut was it? It did not last past the election date because, as soon as that election passed, the ministers got together with the Prime Minister and said that they were going to have to tell the truth to the Australian people, a truth that they had evaded all the way through the election campaign, the truth being that the member for Lalor, the shadow health minister, was right that this Medicare safety net was not affordable-which is what we were saying all along. The health minister is very fond of the word ‘absolutely'. He talks about the Medicare safety net being an absolutely rock solid, ironclad commitment. It made me realise that he does use the word ‘absolutely' a lot. I thought I had better find out where he has been using this word before. On the Four Corners program in 1998, the minister was asked about financial backing for Terry Sharples to help undermine Pauline Hanson. The reporter said, ‘So there was never any question of any party funds or other funds from any other source?' The minister: ‘Absolutely not, absolutely not.' ‘Being offered to Terry Sharples?' The minister: ‘Absolutely not.' So we know whenever this minister uses the words ‘absolutely' or ‘absolute rock solid guarantee' he means exactly the opposite, because he was not telling the truth on the Four Corners program in 1998 and he was not telling the truth in the lead-up to the last election when he said this was an absolute commitment. And we wonder why. Because the standard of truth is set by the Prime Minister, who said, ‘Truth is absolute; truth is supreme; truth is never disposable in national political life.' And here we are-the truth overboard yet again. There is the Treasurer: he was in on the act too. He was in on the act before the last election saying: ‘Absolutely. This will remain an ironclad promise. We will deliver in full after the next election.' But they all knew the truth. They just did not want the Australian people to know the truth, and that is that the cost of the Medicare safety net had blown out.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Order! It being 2 pm, the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 97. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed. NA

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS
text: I inform the House that the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs will be absent from question time today. He is in Melbourne to address an important function of the Council for Multicultural Australia. The Attorney-General will answer questions on his behalf. NA

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Acting Prime Minister. Does the Acting Prime Minister recall saying the following yesterday in relation to the 104-page Telstra report about job losses: ... the Australian Labor Party ... asked questions about some report on the staffing of Telstra into the future ... It forced Telstra to release a statement yesterday which said that there was no such report. Is the Acting Prime Minister aware that yesterday Telstra government relations chief, Phil Burgess, admitted the document did exist? He said, ‘That document is a live document.' Did the Acting Prime Minister mislead the parliament into believing this report did not exist just before the parliament finally dealt with the Telstra sale legislation?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question is no, I did not mislead the House. I have seen the media reports this morning. The only comment that I would make is that Telstra made a statement to the ASX, and that is a matter between Telstra and the ASX.

Speaker: Mr HAASE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister. Would the Acting Prime Minister inform the House how the $3.1 billion Connect Australia package will ensure that all Australians have adequate telecommunications services both now and into the future?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Kalgoorlie for his question. The member represents the largest electorate in Australia, which covers a great expanse of Western Australia. He has been a very keen supporter of this package to ensure that there is an opportunity to invest significantly in telecommunications infrastructure well into the future and to give certainty to all Australians and particularly to regional Australians. Telstra The Connect Australia telecommunications package will give Australians access to first-class telecommunications services, with a $1.1 billion roll-out of broadband and mobile phone services. It will also deliver a $2 billion perpetual Communications Fund, which will deliver on a yearly basis an earning stream to invest in future telecommunications needs across regional Australia. It delivers a more robust regulatory framework and it enhances competition. It also strengthens safeguards to protect consumers. The package has received support not only in the Senate and the House of Representatives but also across Australia from a number of interested groups throughout the community. I give some examples: the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, ATUG, told the Senate hearing last Friday that it supports this package. Yesterday the National Farmers Federation threw their weight behind the package. They said it should be supported; it should go through. They want to see this investment in telecommunications in regional Australia. Most importantly, today, in the Australian, Dick Estens has Telstra thrown his support behind the package. Dick Estens is the man who conducted the most comprehensive review of regional and rural telecommunications in Australia. He said he supports the Connect Australia package. Mr Tanner-He's a member of the National Party.

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: It is interesting that the Labor Party are interjecting and making a lot out of this, but Dick Estens did the most comprehensive review of telecommunications in Australia's history. I do not recall Labor Party in government ever doing such a report. In today's paper, Mr Estens said: I'm happy about the end of the process. move on to the next phase, which is now on building Telstra and building competition in gional Australia. Mr Estens and his committee gave the government the road map to move forward in respect of investment needs in regional telecommunications across Australia. This package that has now passed both houses delivers on Mr Estens' recommendations. Telstra

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Acting Prime Minister. Acting Prime Minister, now that the parliament has passed the Telstra legislation, with some members of your own party not supporting it, how does it feel to have sold out your constituency in rural and regional Australia? Acting Prime Minister, isn't it a fact that you will be forever known as the Nationals leader who sold out the bush?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Before calling the Acting Prime Minister, I believe the first half of that question was asking for an opinion. The Acting Prime Minister may answer the question.

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The answer to the second part of the question is no. How do I feel? I feel very good because this is the biggest investment in telecommunications in regional Australia. On the day that the Labor Party's former leader has opened the book on the Australian Labor Party, on every single member that sits on the front bench and on the Leader of the Opposition, I say to the Labor Party and to all those who voted against this package that they have voted against the opportunity to invest $3.1 billion in regional telecommunications. They have voted against the opportunity to ensure a better regulatory framework. They have the voted against the opportunity to improve competition in telecommunications in regional Australia. The government very Let's proudly supports what we have put forward. As I said in my earlier answer, this package re- delivers on the Estens inquiry and it delivers the largest investment in regional telecommunications in this country's history. Telstra

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer outline the benefits that will flow to consumers from the full sale of Telstra and from the establishment of a telecommunications fund? Treasurer, are there any alternative positions?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Moncrieff for his question. Today is a historic day here in the parliament because the ownership and the status of Telstra have been finally resolved, and resolved in a way which will put this carrier on a modern, competitive footing to deliver good services to the people of Australia over decades to come. It was back in 1993 that the coalition, then in opposition, first proposed privatisation in relation to Telstra. Back in those days of course the Australian Labor Party was very gung-ho about privatisation, privatising Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank. This idea that the Labor Party has always opposed privatisation-you would have to have a short memory to actually believe that for a moment. Our government have been up front and honest about our policies. We believe that telecommunications can be delivered by the private sector, as indeed it is in countries like the United States, the United Kingdom and New Zealand-in fact, in most of the modern developed economies of the world. We have resolved the status of Telstra ownership whilst putting in place a competitive framework so that there is competition to drive prices lower-a competitive framework which has been endorsed by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. We have also invested in a regional telecommunications fund. That will be a $2 billion fund, the earnings of which will be available to upgrade services in regional areas for decades to come-an investment that would not have been made if Telstra had remained with majority government control. Mr Tanner interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order! The member for Melbourne!

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I spoke earlier of the Australian Labor Party's penchant for privatisation. There is one big difference between this government and Labor. When Labor privatised the banks and the airlines, it spent the total capital in full in the year of receipt and then still drove the budget into deficit. the end of the year, there were no shares, there was a bigger budget deficit and there were greater borrowings. Labor totally dissipated the proceeds of the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas. Our government believe that the proceeds should be invested for future generations. We will do that through the Future Fund to give young Australians opportunities in the future-a sound financial footing from a government that has set this country up to cope with the impacts of demographic change. This matter has been finally resolved. It has been resolved in a way which will bring competitive industry, better prices and better investment in regional Australia and set young Australians up for a much better future over decades to come. Telstra

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Acting Prime Minister. Can the Acting Prime Minister inform the House whether his office or the Prime Minister's office made any contact with ASIC on the evening of 13 September or the morning of 14 September? Can the Acting Prime Minister assure the House that there was no ministerial or staff interference with ASIC's original intention to investigate the Prime Minister over his infamous remarks that Telstra executives should ‘talk up' the company?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. I can certainly inform him that I made no such contact and, as far as I am aware, no staff in my office or in the Prime Minister's office made any contact with ASIC. I understand that the Treasurer answered this question in full yesterday, but I will check on those staff. Telecommunications

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister. Would the Acting Prime Minister inform the At House how the government is strengthening regulation in the telecommunications sector?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Hinkler for his question. I again recognise the invaluable contribution that the member for Hinkler has made with regard to telecommunications across Australia for the entirety of his time in this place. The member for Hinkler asked about consumer protection. The government have strengthened consumer protection in four key areas as part of the $3.1 billion Connect Australia package that was passed through the parliament this week. We are reaffirming the universal service obligation-let us never, ever forget that it was our government that introduced, through legislation, the universal service obligation. We are strengthening the customer service guarantee, something else that our government introduced. We are improving the network reliability framework and requiring Telstra to submit a local presence plan. The government has reaffirmed the universal service obligation in its commitment to providing basic phone services in rural and regional areas. The government has strengthened the CSG so that Telstra and all other phone companies must connect and repair phone services quickly or pay compensation. The government has increased the amount of compensation by 21 per cent with regard to this. On an issue that I know the member for Hinkler is very interested in, the government will ensure that phone companies cannot use the mass disruption clause to unreasonably claim exemptions from the customer service guarantee. The government has also tightened the network reliability framework, which requires Telstra to monitor the number of faults in its lines and upgrade them if they have repeated faults. As part of that, Telstra will now be required to upgrade at least 480 cable runs of its copper network a year, as determined by the Australian Communications and Media Authority. The government will review the network reliability framework in 2007 and tighten it even further if necessary. This package is about giving regional and rural Australia certainty and confidence-not just today but into the future-that, regardless of who owns Telstra, there will be a visible and effective presence in rural and regional Australia and their services will be provided.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Treasurer. Does the Treasurer recall saying to the House yesterday: ... I can confirm that certainly my office has been in touch with Mr Lucy. Did any member of the Treasurer's staff in any conversation with Mr Lucy or any member of ASIC's staff suggest in any way that an inquiry into statements made by the Prime Minister was unwelcome or that a public statement that such an inquiry was not occurring should be made?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: As I said yesterday, my office was in contact with ASIC, as I would expect it to be, so that I could be briefed to answer questions in the parliament. The suggestion that my office in some way directed ASIC is absolutely false, as I said yesterday. Mr Crean interjecting

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: It is absolutely false and unwelcome. Are there any other adjectives you would like? No? The Chairman of ASIC is a statutory officer who is protected by statute and who is given a statutory responsibility to administer the law. As I said yesterday, if ASIC wants to investigate the Prime Minister, I would welcome it to do so. He will not have been in contravention of the act for one second. Why? Because the duty of disclosure is not on the Prime Minister; as I told the House yesterday, the duty of disclosure is on Telstra. It does not matter; the Prime Minister never, ever had an obligation to make statements to the Australian Stock Exchange. Mr Tanner-He's still at liberty, Pete.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Telstra has an obligation to make a disclosure to the Australian Stock Exchange, and Telstra maintains that it did make a disclosure to the Australian Stock Exchange. As I said yesterday, ASIC will Telstra investigate whether or not it made proper disclosure. Mr Tanner interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Melbourne is warned!

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: ASIC are welcome to ask anybody they like any question they like in order to determine Telstra's obligation. As far as this side of the House is concerned, we would welcome them and we would invite them and we would encourage them to do so. They know they have the statutory powers to do so, and they will operate them in a way which is consistent with those powers. Economy

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is also addressed to the Treasurer. Treasurer, what are the challenges ahead for economic management in the year ahead? Are there any alternative views on how to manage the economy, and are they credible?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. There will be significant challenges in the year ahead to manage the economy. For example, the rising petrol price will undoubtedly add to inflation. It will be felt in full in the September CPI. As the Reserve Bank has already said in its August statement on monetary policy, in the near term headline CPI inflation is likely to be above underlying inflation, reflecting the pass-through of the current strength in oil prices. But underlying inflation is expected to increase gradually. In other words, the petrol price will go into the CPI. It will move the CPI up, but what the bank will do and what the government will focus on is underlying inflation when you take that first-round effect out. We will, of course, look at secondround effects if it gets into the general economy. In addition to that, the task ahead in relation to economic policy will also be to manage current global imbalances, particularly imbalances between savings in investment between China and the United States. The task ahead will be to reform the industrial relations system. The task ahead will be to bed down a competitive regime in relation to Telstra. Are there any alternative views on managing the economy? The opposition did say that they planned this term to build their credibility in relation to the economy. Those of us who fought the last election will recall that during the last election the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Latham, fought the campaign on the basis that all he had to do to keep interest rates down was to sign a big pledge and that, once he had pledged to keep interest rates down, that was it. Members of the opposition might laugh at that proposition, but they put out leaflets all over Australia claiming that the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Mark Latham, would be able to keep interest rates down. I have an election leaflet which was an open letter to the people of Western Australia. On the front of it is a letter which was signed by Kim C Beazley. The opposition would have you believe today that Mr Latham is erratic or untruthful or cannot be believed. That was not the story 12 months ago during the federal election. Mr Swan-What was your story 12 months ago? Mr Tanner-What do you say about John Howard?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I want to say what this leaflet reads. It has a lovely photo of the current Leader of the Opposition and the former leader, Mr Mark Latham. Here is what it says: Labor is ready to govern and Mark Latham is ready to be Prime Minister. We have a letter which is signed by Kim C Beazley which says, ‘Labor is ready to govern and Mark Latham is ready to be Prime Minister.' Mr Swan-When are you going to be ready?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Member for Lilley!

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Both of those comments were false. Labor is not ready to govern, and there would be no Australian today who believes that Mark Latham is, was or ever will be ready to be Prime Minister. Why would Kim C Beazley circulate that to the people of Western Australia? There are two alternatives. Maybe he has no judgment and really did believe that Labor was ready to govern under Prime Minister Latham, or maybe he did not believe it and he was less than honest with the people of Western Australia: ‘Labor is ready to govern and Mark Latham is ready to be Prime Minister.' Mr Tanner-Can't you do better than this?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Melbourne has been warned!

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: This weekend some of us are looking forward to going to the football. Some of us are looking forward to having some time off. As for myself, I am going to tuck myself away with a good book for a quiet read. When I am reading that book I will be thinking to myself, ‘These are diaries of the man Kim C Beazley thoughtMr Swan interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Lilley is warned!

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: was ready to be Prime Minister.' Whatever he says todayMr Stephen Smith interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Perth!

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: he put this man forward as a credible leader of the country less than 12 months ago.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Perth is warned!

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Those pen portraits are not the pen portraits of somebody who cannot be believed. They are the pen portraits of the person whom Labor trusted to lead it and asked the country to follow in the election of October 2004. I table that leaflet. Telstra

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. How does the minister respond to the grave concern expressed by the ACCC chair that laws to promote competition against Telstra are unenforceable? Why was I not to be provided with answers to my questions to you on Monday on the closure of Telstra HiBIS installations, on the inability of satellite to handle voice over internet and on increased rural access prices, until after the sale legislation passed the parliament?

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Now that the legislation has passed through the parliament, the next step is the development of an operational separation plan. The ACCC is obviously going to be extensively involved with the government in developing the operational separation arrangements. It already has been and will continue to be in the future. Certainly the ACCC has made it clear in the past that it has concerns about the structural arrangements in the telecommunications industry. Indeed we know that from Mr Graeme Samuel's comments at the Senate inquiry held last Friday. But, at the same time, the ACCC has agreed that the government's model is workable. It indicated at those committee hearings that it believes there are a number of matters relating to operational separation that have to be carefully addressed during the process of developing the operational separation plan. So the interests of regional and rural subscribers as well as the interests of all Australians will be served by this discussion and negotiation between the ACCC and the government in drawing up the operational separation plan. There is no mystery to this. It is as would be entirely expected. The views of Mr Samuel and his colleagues, of course, will weigh heavily with the government. In regard to providing information in answer to the honourable member's last question some days ago, I understand that Senator Coonan is in the process of replying in detail. Employment

Speaker: Mrs MARKUS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister update the House on today's figures for long-term unemployment in Australia? What does the government plan to do to continue to reduce long-term unemployment?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Greenway for her question and for her interest in ensuring that people in her electorate of Greenway can find jobs. Today's ABS figures show that long-term unemployment in Australia is at a 19-year low. This comes on top of the figures of last week which show that the unemployment rate in Australia, at five per cent, is at a 29-year low.
