That means that there are now 88,700 people in Australia who are long-term unemployedthat is, who have been unemployed for 12 months or more. Compare this to the situation in 1993, when the Leader of the Opposition was the minister for employment and the long-term unemployed numbered 330,000that is, there is a difference of almost a quarter of a million long-term unemployed between the figures in 1993 and the figures released by the ABS today. The attitude taken by the governments of the day stand in marked contrast. On 6 May 1993 the Leader of the Opposition, then the minister for employment, was asked this during an interview on The 7.30 Report on ABC Television: PAUL LYNEHAM: So this groupthat is, the unemployedare being told, in their twenties, by society, effectively: You're the losers; go to the scrap heap. KIM BEAZLEY: Well, those who haven't made it into work and who are among the long-term unemployed, that's a reasonable statement. … … … PAUL LYNEHAM: So a worse case scenario could see itlong-term unemploymentat half a million? KIM BEAZLEY: Well, close to that-a worse case scenario, yes ... Where it is now is unacceptable; where it's going to is even more unacceptable. There is a stark contrast between that attitude, which says, ‘We're not worried about the long-term unemployed,' and the attitude taken by our government to reduce the numbers by almost quarter of a million. The $3.6 billion of welfare to work measures we are taking include $360 million over four years to help the long-term unemployed into work. We think 88,000 is too many-and 330,000, when the Labor Party was in government, was an absolute disgrace. Amongst this expenditure are measures for extra places in the personal support program, extra places for vocational rehabilitation, extra Wage Assist places and a $50 million employer demand strategy. What this is all about is the government getting on with the job. It is about providing more jobs, higher wages and greater opportunities for Australians, including those who are unemployed for the long term. The best form of welfare that we can provide our fellow Australians is to enable them to get a job, and that is what we are about. Senator Barnaby Joyce

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Acting Prime Minister. Will the Acting Prime Minister confirm that he attended the Canberra Hospital on the evening of 13 September to visit Senator Barnaby Joyce? Mrs Bronwyn Bishop- Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. Under the standing orders the member may only ask questions of the minister about matters that relate to his portfolio responsibilities, and they certainly do not relate to visiting someone in a hospital.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Mackellar. Let me make two points. First of all, the member has not completed her question, so it is very hard to rule on it. Secondly, the Acting Prime Minister now has responsibility across all portfolios. I call the Manager of Opposition Business.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Thank you, Mr Speaker. I will start my question again. Will the Acting Prime Minister confirm that he attended the Canberra Hospital on the evening of 13 September to visit Senator Barnaby Joyce? Will the Acting Prime Minister also confirm that he was refused access to Senator Joyce? Isn't it true that, when refused access, the Acting Prime Minister directed an AFP officer to try to misuse his authority in order to gain access?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The answer to the first part of the member for Lalor's question is yes, as any leader of any political party would also have compassion for their colleagues. The answer to the second part of her question is no. Health Reform Miss JACKIE KELLY (2.31 pm)-My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister outline to the House the government's commitment to health reform? How has the government already reformed our Medicare system? Are there any alternative policies?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Lindsay for her question. I note that, thanks to the reforms that this government has put in place, the GP bulk-billing rate in the electorate of Lindsay has gone up to 89.5 per cent. As the Prime Minister and all the state Labor premiers recently concluded, Australia already has an excellent health system. The policies and reforms of this government are making a good system even better. We have boosted bulk-billing rates for children and country people to an all-time high; we have increased medical student numbers by 30 per cent; we have introduced a Medicare safety net that will help 1½ million people next year; and we are working with the states to ensure better coordination between different health programs and more seamless delivery of health services. I have been asked about alternative policies. There are no serious alternative policies, because members opposite are now indulging in an orgy of political cannibalism. Back in December the shadow minister for health said of Mark Latham: ‘Can I say that my faith in him is undiminished.' In fact, the shadow minister for health and the former member for Werriwa seemed to have had the undying political devotion to each other of Lord and Lady Macbeth. Perhaps health reform was discussed at a dinner the shadow minister for health attended last night. It is a new Labor dining society. Labor MPs have put all their eggs in the one basket case. Of course they are not interested in health reform because, according to the former leader, the current Leader of the Opposition is more interested in preparing a dirt file than he is in developing good policy. This is what the former leader says of the current leader: ‘People are still writing Beazley up as a decent loser, but he is one of the most indecent politicians I have come across.' When Labor MPs were last asked to choose between health reform and health inertiaMs Gillard- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order on relevance. I was wondering if the minister could explain whether he is the best friend David Clarke has ever had.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: There is no point of order.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: At least there is a bit of friendship on this side of the House.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: We are friends on this side of the House. We are not ‘snakes' and ‘sewer rats'-words out of your own mouths. The last time Labor members were asked to choose between health reform and health inertia-between Mark Latham and Kim Beazley-Kim Beazley lost. Labor members trusted Mark Latham more than they trusted Kim Beazley. I went onto Labor's web site yesterday looking for their health policy. Today I went back on their web site. What did I find? I found some political clothing. Mr Costello-Merchandising.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Political merchandising. On 15 September-this very day-it is available on the Australian Labor Party web site. It says, ‘Mark Latham for PM.' They will not hang his portrait in their party room but they are still flogging his T-shirt. It was $30; now $15. I bet they will be giving them away tomorrow. What this proves is that there are still people opposite who would always prefer mad Mark to cowardly Kim. Opposition members-Ooh! Mr Beazley interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The minister will withdraw that last remark.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: If he is upset, I am happy to withdraw it.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: No.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Even if he is not upset I am happy to withdraw it. Ammonium Nitrate

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question without notice is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Can the minister confirm that thousands of tonnes of ammonium nitrate is shipped to Australian ports in flag of convenience vessels operating under single-voyage permits which can be issued within 24 hours of an application being lodged with the Department of Transport and Regional Services? Can he also confirm that the department relies on information provided by the master of the vessel seeking the permit as to the identity of the crew members? How can the minister guarantee that thousands of tonnes of highly explosive material being shipped into Australian ports is secure when the system for issuing shipping permits is wide open to abuse?

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The answer to the first part of the question is that certainly a large quantity of ammonium nitrate is shipped into Australia. We have significant demands for this product with our burgeoning mining industry, and of course ammonium nitrate is also important in agriculture. So significant quantities of ammonium nitrate come to Australia. About 99 per cent of our trade is involved with foreign ships, so it is quite likely that a significant proportion of it comes in on foreign ships. Mr Bevis-Flag of convenience ships.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: But it is not true to say that these ships come in without any checking. The reality is that we have a substantial, comprehensive risk assessment process in place. Mr Bevis-Ask the ship's master.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Brisbane has asked his question.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Each ship is subject to security checking irrespective of its flag. In addition to that, the members of the crew are checked against any alert lists to make sure that they do not pose a risk to Australia. If they choose to enter Australia, they must go through the same kinds of immigration checks as anyone else coming into this country. The Leader of the Opposition was in Gladstone a few weeks ago on that accidentprone trip and tried to make something of the fact that ammonium nitrate was being moved between Australian ports on ships that had a single-voyage permit. The reality is that the alternative to moving ammonium nitrate around Australia by ship is to move it by truck. Instead of this ammonium nitrate going from Sydney to Gladstone by ship, it could have gone by truck. It would have taken 500 semitrailers to make that journey. And which do you think is safer-500 semitrailers going up the road or one ship? The reality is that we have a safety regime in place. It is much safer to transport ammonium nitrate by ship than by road. I think Australian public would want us to continue that kind of transport regime. Gaza Strip

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Attorney General and Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Attorney General aware of public comments critical of Israel which accuse Israel of ethnic cleansing in East Jerusalem, creating a walled ghetto, giant penal colony and a concentration camp in the Gaza Strip? If so, what is the Attorney's response to these comments, which compare Israel's conduct with that which occurred in the Holocaust and other more recent tragedies?

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am aware of the statement made by the member for Fowler in this House on Tuesday evening when she accused Israel of planning to ‘rule Gaza like a walled ghetto, a giant penal colony, a concentration camp'. Through our linkages with the community or even family linkages, many of us know that millions of Jewish people died in concentration camps in World War II. It was an enormous crime against humanity. To make this sort of comparison belittles the suffering, pain and anguish of those who were left so tragically behind and the death of those who died a dastardly death in those concentration camps. As the foreign minister has told this House before, Prime Minister Sharon's disengagement initiative is a positive step by the Israeli government towards bringing about the goals of the road map for the Middle East, which the Australian government strongly supports. Likewise, the government welcomed Palestinian President Abbas's commitment to stopping terrorism and incitement to further bloodshed in the context of that disengagement. On these matters, the government believed that it had bipartisan the support for these views. Obviously the comments of the member for Fowler are quite contemptuous of these matters.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: As the member for Sturt has said, I think that the Leader of the Opposition should immediately discipline Mrs Irwin. He must insist that she apologise for her remarks. She must be required to withdraw them in the House. At the very a least, because he may not be able to do that, he should disassociate himself from those statements, which should not go unchallenged. Ammonium Nitrate

text: Manager of Opposition Business, I can rule on this point of order without assistance. As the member for Canning would have noticed, I have called on the Leader of the Opposition to come straight to his question. I call the Leader of the Opposition and ask him to get straight to his question.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Acting Prime Minister. Is the Acting Prime Minister aware that a foreign vessel, the Thor Hawk, was trading on the Australian coast last week, carrying dangerous cargoes, including ammonium nitrate. Isn't it the case that this vessel is in such poor condition while in Newcastle, its crane broke, dropping the volatile cargo into the ship's hatch and putting lives at risk? Is the Acting Prime Minister aware that fuel mixed with ammonium nitrate is potentially lethal and that the ship's engineer did not even know how to attach the fuel line when the vessel was refuelled in Gladstone? Given the complacent attitude of the transport minister displayed in his answer to the last question from the opposition, why should any Australian trust the Howard government to keep us safe from a terrorist act or accident involving ammonium nitrate?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. I am not aware of the detail of the circumstances that he refers to in his question, but I can assure the members of the opposition and the Australian people that the coalition government is absolutely focused on keeping Australia and all Australians safe and secure both at home and abroad. Building and Construction Industry

Speaker: Mr HENRY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister update the House on the government's measures to reform the building and construction industry? How will the industry and home buyers benefit from these reforms?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Hasluck for his question. I can inform him that today I was delighted to announce the appointment of the Hon. John Lloyd as the first Australian Building and Construction Commissioner. Mr Lloyd brings a long background of involvement in industrial relations at the state level as well as the Commonwealth level, most recently as a senior deputy president of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, to this role. What the establishment of the ABCC in that, volves is the culmination of a four-year process commencing with the royal commission under Mr Justice Cole, which established a clear and undeniable case for a comprehensive clean-up of the building and construction industry. The Econtech report of a few years ago showed that the benefit of cleaning up the unlawful practices in the commercial building and construction industry could be worth up to $2.3 billion to the Australian economy, yet the ALP has opposed every single measure that the government has put forward in an endeavour to do this. We have had some more examples today in the media. Yesterday the Western Australian Assistant Secretary of the CFMEU, Joe Macdonald, was convicted of assaulting two managers of a Perth building site after he attempted to gain unauthorised entryanother example of this sort of behaviour. Then we have seen another report where the full bench of the Federal Court ruled that the Victorian government, having resisted providing documents to the Building Industry Task Force for some 2½ years-at a cost of some tens if not hundreds of thousands of dollars to Victorian taxpayers-must hand over documents in relation to an investigation into allegations that it manipulated a government tender process to award contracts to a company that was favoured by the CFMEU. This is serious. This is an allegation of a deliberate manipulation of a government contract so that it did not go to a company that employed non-unionists in relation to this tender. The point of this is that, if a ment can succumb to union pressure, what hope have the little subcontractors out on the building sites around Australia? It is another example of why the establishment of the Australian Building and Construction Commission is long overdue. When it comes into operation from the beginning of October this year it might finally bring about a change in the culture and the behaviour in the commercial building sector in Australia. What this shows once again is that this side of the chamber, this side of politics in Australia, is about law abiding and productive building and construction sites in Australia and that the Labor Party, in fighting this tooth and nail, year after year, stands for the protection of the rackets and the rorts that go on in the building and construction sector. That is a reality. Mr Crean-Rubbish! It is not a reality and you know it!

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Hotham knows it because they were not prepared to do a thing about it. Mr Crean-Tell the truth!

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order! The member for Hotham is warned!

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Only this government has been prepared to do something about it. What they want to protect is the thuggery and the intimidation that goes on within this industry-the sort of thuggery and intimidation where, in order to get access to a building site, we have had instances of the building and construction section of the CFMEU saying that you have to pay $1,000 for a number of T-shirts in order to get access to a building and construction site. Mr Costello-T-shirts?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: T-shirts. Speaking of T shirts, before anybody rushes out to get the Mark Latham T-shirt and cap: it was taken state governoff the web site at 2.43! Veterans Affairs

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Can the minister confirm that she received correspondence from the member for Blair earlier this year about her approach to compensation for service personnel affected by the RAAF's F111 deseal-reseal program? Did the member for Blair advise you in the letter that ‘the regime of support now proposed is an insult' and ‘unless this regime is corrected and replaced quickly the defence community will have been ripped off again'? When will the minister cease misleading these people, who have served their country well, on their real prospects of compensation? Will you now reconsider this totally inadequate scheme?

Speaker: Mrs DEANNE KELLY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: ANNE KELLY-I thank the member for Oxley for his question. I did receive a letter from the member for Blair. However, I would like to refer to his request and his statement that the ex gratia payments for F111 desealers-resealers are inadequate. He may be aware that the announcement was for $40,000 ex gratia for those who had the most effect from the environmental hazard and $10,000 for those who had a lesser effect. By 15 September we had received 616 claims for the ex gratia payments. Evidently, those who are affected believe that the claims are worth making. I would also like to inform the member for Oxley that that is not the only amount that these people are entitled to if they have had illness or injury due to their Defence Force service. In fact, for somebody who has had a severe illness as a result of their defence service, such as Parkinson's disease-for instance, a 50-year-old person expected to live perhaps to 75 yearsMr Ripoll-What about desealersresealers? That's the whole point.

Speaker: Mrs DEANNE KELLY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: ANNE KELLY-These people are desealers-resealers. Somebody like that would be entitled to a lump sum, including fortnightly payments, of $596,000. Were they to die, their widow would be entitled to an amount of $247,837. So the amounts are not insignificant. Mr Ripoll interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order! The member for Oxley has already asked his question.

Speaker: Mrs DEANNE KELLY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: ANNE KELLY-Let me comment on what the Labor Party said about resealers-desealers. Your party was asked a question when it was in government and this was the response from the minister assisting. Mr Ripoll- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. My question was very specific. I did not ask for any alternative views or about what the Labor Party did. I was just seeking a clarification

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I call the minister.

Speaker: Mrs DEANNE KELLY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: ANNE KELLY-The then assisting Minister for Defence was asked: ... what danger does close contact with such solvent pose to human health ... in regard to F111 reseal-deseal aircraft? The then minister assisting, Minister Evans, said: It is considered that the safety measures described at 3b. above fulfil this purpose. In other words, that they had been fully taken account of. You did nothing as a party when in government about resealers-desealers. I also want to comment on other Labor individuals who have made reference to the ex gratia payment. I read from a letter dated 25 August. It says: The Queensland government supports the decision of the Department of Veterans' Affairs to make a lump sum ex gratia payment to all Defence personnel and contractors. Tom Barton, Minister for Employment, Training and Industrial Relations. The reality is that you as a Labor Party did nothing in government. Now we have come out with an ex gratia payment and even the Queensland government supports it.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Before calling the next questioner, I remind the Minister for Veterans' Affairs that the use of ‘you' and ‘your' is highly discouraged. Education: Literacy

Speaker: Mr WOOD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Is the minister aware of concerns about English standards for Australian school leavers? What is the government doing to improve standards in our schools? Are there any alternative policies?

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for La Trobe for his question and for proudly being a member of a government committed to high national standards in schooling. I awoke this morning to a headline in the Australian newspaper entitled ‘Students unable to write a sentence'. The story is that there has been a survey of 660 Australian Defence Force Academy students and it reports that intelligent students are graduating from high school and entering university with writing skills so poor that they are not able to structure a sentence. In fact, the ADFA Associate Dean of Education, Stephen Yeomans, is reported as saying: What I particularly notice is improper sentence construction, inappropriate or no punctuation, lack of conjunctives, misuse of apostrophes, poor spelling and so on. The average Australian would probably think that Australia's minister for education would be shocked to read such a headline and to read such a study. The only thing that is shocking about it is that I am not shocked; in fact, I am not even surprised. In this particular study-we are talking about students who achieved a tertiary entrance rank of 80 or more-only one in six of those students could achieve 70 per cent accuracy in basic grammar. Just to put that into some context, there are students who have been accepted into Australian universities this yearMr Snowdon interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Lingiari is warned!

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: to train as teachers, with tertiary entrance scores in the low 50s. In the Saturday Age, the front-page story was ‘VCE English “dumbed down”: one book a year could be enough under “English lite”'students would have to read only one single book in year 12. I would also point out to the House-and I am happy to table these-that I have three examples of minimum passing results by students in the year 12 Higher School Certificate in New South Wales. One student, for a 40-minute essay question, was able to write only 63 words. That essay included spelling mistakes and 21 of the words repeated the question. That student passed year 12 advanced English in New South Wales and presumably now is undertaking a university program. The government is doing three things to address this. The first is that very shortly I will be receiving the report of the national inquiry into reading. I am informed by the chairman that 30 per cent of Australian children are leaving the education system essentially malfunctioning, as far as their basic literacy and ability to read is concerned. The second is that the member for Cowper, very ably supported by the member for Port Adelaide, is conducting an inquiry into the training of teachers in Australian universitiesand there will be major reform. The third is that the government is driving an Australian certificate of education. We are determined through the Australian Council of Education to drive a nationally-consistent high-quality year 12 qualification. I also inform the House that I will be commissioning some independent work to assess the academic rigour of English, chemistry, physics and mathematics at the year 12 level throughout Australia and I will be making it available to communities so that they can compare the standards in one state with another. The battle for international competitiveness is going to be fought and won or lost in Australia's schools. It is not just about the fulfilment of human potential in our children; it is about Australia's place in the world and the standards that we expect. Workplace Relations

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Will the minister confirm that it is government policy that all sole parents who can work should work, even if they are working for little or no financial gain? Does the minister stand by his statement of 25 August that it is government policy for parents to take home as little as $3.88 an hour before they have even paid for child care and other work costs? I refer the minister to a statement made by the Prime Minister on 2 June that parents will not be required to work for ‘a very low or negative financial gain' and I ask him: who is right-the minister or the Prime Minister?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Both the Prime Minister and I are right. I say to the member for Sydney that, as I said the other day, the government believe there are considerable benefits in people being able to work where they are capable of working. We believe that far too many people have been locked out of the economic life of this country. For example, something like 700,000 children in Australia are growing up in jobless households. That is unacceptable, and that is why the government are putting in place some changes in the Welfare to Work measures. In the past the welfare system has been based on the proposition that either people could work full time or they could not work at all. Today there are many people in Australia who work part time and we believe that, if a person is capable of part-time employment, then there should be some obligation to do that. If they do that and work for 15 hours as required at the normal award classification wages for adults, that effectively means that a sole parent on the minimum wage for 15 hours a week will have $484.24 a week to take home. This compares to a sole parent pension recipient who does not work who receives $58 a week less. This is effectively about saying that we are going to give those people an opportunity to be in the economic life of this country and that we are going to do something about stopping the intergenerational poverty which is caused by allowing the current situation to honourable member and her colleagues on the other side of the table were interested in helping out people in that situation, they would get behind these measures. Aged Care

Speaker: Mr SECKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Ageing. Would the minister advise the House how the Howard government will further protect residents of aged care homes who have paid an accommodation bond?

Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Barker for his question and acknowledge his interest in aged care issues in his electorate. The Australian government is committed to ensuring that older Australians have peace of mind while living in aged care homes. Today I announced new measures to strengthen existing protections around accommodation bonds. There will be a new prudential scheme which will strengthen financial management of accommodation bonds, and there will be a guarantee scheme that will ensure that bond balances are repaid in full. Under the prudential scheme approved providers will be required to comply with three prudential standards to enhance and improve the financial management of the bond holdings. Under the guarantee scheme, in the event that there is a default by a provider through bankruptcy or liquidation and there is default in repaying the bond, the government will step in and repay that bond to the resident or their families and then proceed to recover the debt and costs from the provider or, if necessary, to levy the aged care industry. The Australian government is committed to ensuring that older Australians have peace of mind while living in residential care. We are providing an assurance to all residents and their families that their bond go on. If the balances are secure. Mr Vaile- Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. NA House of Representatives: Dress Code

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Yesterday the Chief Opposition Whip asked me a question about dress standards for the chamber galleries. As a matter of routine, staff in the Serjeant-at-Arms' office respond to queries about what clothing is acceptable for visitors in the galleries by saying that it is not acceptable to display political slogans or anything else that could be seen to constitute a protest in the galleries. The Serjeant-at-Arms has advised me that no-one in that office has ever been asked whether it would be acceptable for a large group of visitors to wear into the galleries specialist work clothing with clear purpose of drawing attention to the group. Were this question to be asked, the staff would respond by saying that such clothing would not be acceptable. The rule against protest action in the galleries is long standing and serves to maintain the dignity of the House and its proceedings. The rule is a statement of principle, for, as the honourable member would appreciateand I think all members would appreciate-it would be impossible to have a list of every item of clothing and example of behaviour which would be inappropriate in the galleries. As all honourable members would know, the presumption is that persons attending in the galleries of the chamber do so to observe the proceedings of the House. It is not appropriate for any persons in the galleries to engage in behaviour which would be likely to draw attention to themselves or to disturb other observers in the galleries. In the particular case raised by the Chief Opposition Whip, I understand that it was the intention of a group of firefighters visiting the galleries to wear their specialist protective clothing with large reflective panels on the chest and leg areas. I appreciate that all members of the group complied with the request to remove the outer specialist clothing before they entered the gallery. I believe it would be unacceptable behaviour for a large group of persons attending question time to wear into a gallery clothing which, by its very purpose, is intended to draw attention to the wearer. It would be very difficult to interpret this action as anything other than a protest or disturbance in the gallery of the chamber. I, like all members, heartily welcome the attendance in the chamber galleries of visitors to this place, including firefighters, who are able to attend and observe parliamentary proceedings. Nevertheless, it would be inapthe propriate to permit any behaviour whose purpose is to divert attention away from the parliamentary proceedings.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, on that point: the interpretation of that ruling would be that if a member of the Australian Defence Force walked into the gallery wearing a camouflage uniform as opposed to their dress uniform, they would in fact offend that ruling.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his observation. I would ask the Leader of the Opposition to read the whole statement and I think it will become clear to him what the ruling is.  Speaker, I sincerely thank you for reporting back to the House. I would not wish in any way to reflect on the ruling you have just given, but I might take up one of the opportunities you extend to members to further discuss things.

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: In relation to the ruling that you have just given about distincgovernment tive and particular work clothing, and given the context in which it has been referred to, those uniforms that many people wear as distinctive and unique work clothing is designed specifically to draw attention to their House. uniqueness. That does not simply include individual military personnel who may come here from time to time either in their dress uniform or in their camouflage uniform; from time to time it also includes large numbers of military personnel who come here precisely in their uniform, as a group, to draw attention to their presence as a group. In the context of the statement you have just made, will you look at that situation and consider whether or not your statement requires some adjustment?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the member for Brisbane, and I refer him to my answer to the Leader of the Opposition. NA  Secretary to the Treasurer) (3.10 pm)- Mr Speaker, on indulgence: given that the parliament is not scheduled to meet again before the AFL Grand Final, as a fellow Victorian I am sure you will join with me in wishing St Kilda all the best in their quest. NA

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Yes.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

The same matters were raised in question time today by the Attorney-General. The member for Sturt and the Attorney-General said that I should be required to withdraw the statements in the Mr Brough-Where have you been misrepresented?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Order! The member for Fowler has the call.

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: My remarks are not intended to offend Jewish people. If the words ‘concentration camp' and ‘ethnic cleansing' offend the House I withdraw them, but I would expect Jewish people to recognise the human rights abuses I detailed in my speech on Tuesday more than most people would. I will always remain passionate about justice not only for Palestinians but

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The member for Fowler will resume her seat. The member for Fowler has made her point. Ms Panopoulos- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. That was extremely disturbing. The member for Fowler rose, claiming that she was misrepresented

text: There is no point of order.  tary to the Minister for Health and Ageing) (3.12 pm)- Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Please proceed.  ferred to my press release issued today regarding her disgraceful remarks about the state of Israel in the adjournment debate on Tuesday and claimed that I had misrepresented her. If you check the record of the Hansard, you will find that my press release entirely replicates her disgraceful and embarrassing speech which she should have apologised for. It did not just offend Jewish people; it offended all people

Speaker: The SPEAKER

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, on two occasions this week in the context of the government's legislation to fully privatise Telstra and the National Party, I have been required to withdraw the word ‘bribe'-once when the member for Page, Mr Causley, was in the chair, despite the fact that it is a word he has used himself; and on a second occasion when you were in the chair this morning. Mr Speaker, you made a ruling in respect of these matters yesterday, as recorded in the daily Hansard at page 59, where you refer to the atmosphere in the chamber at the time being important. This morning, again in that same context of the government's legislation and the National Party, when the member for Mackellar, Mrs Bronwyn Bishop was in the chair, my colleague the member for Hotham formally moved a second reading amendment which stated at paragraph (2)(h): … the bribe used to guarantee the sale of Telstra will consign regional, rural and remote Australians to second rate telecommunications services in the future. My question of you, Mr Speaker, is whether it is appropriate to use the word ‘bribe' in the written form but not in the oral form, or whether it is the case that the atmosphere or the ambience of the chamber is only satisfied when Bronnie is in the chair.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Order! The member for Perth need not make that last point. I will respond to his question, nonetheless. In relation to the first part of his question, I refer him back to my statement. In relation to proceedings this morning when I was in the chair, I would draw the honourable member's attention to standing order 89, which says quite clearly: A Member must not use offensive words against: (a) either House of the Parliament or a Member of the Parliament ... I think that is quite clear. As the member would recall, the member for Perth was referring to a senator. NA

Speaker: Mrs BRONWYN BISHOP
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Does the member for Mackellar claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mrs BRONWYN BISHOP
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Yes, indeed I have.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mrs BRONWYN BISHOP
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The member for Perth rose and referred to a ruling that I was not obliged to make, because there was no question raised this morning. The point about it is that in the written amendment the word does not attach to any individual, which is what the standing orders do not allow. Mr Speaker, the point that you just made is a valid one except that it goes further: the word must be attached, as no doubt the Clerk will advise, to an individual. In the case of the amendment, that did not happen. However, had the matter been raised with me, had anyone draw my attention to it this morning, I might have ruled otherwise.

Speaker: Mr CAMERON THOMPSON
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Does the member for Blair claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr CAMERON THOMPSON
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Yes.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr CAMERON THOMPSON
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Today during question time the member for Oxley referred to a letter from me to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs dated 21 January 2005 that referred to the deseal-reseal program. When that letter was put forward that did not refer to the ex-gratia system that is currently offered by the minister. Mr Ripoll- Mr Speaker, on a point of order: where is the misrepresentation?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Order! The member for Oxley will resume his seat. I am endeavouring to hear where the member for Blair claims to have been misrepresented. If members would allow him to be heard in silence we might be able to find out. The member for Blair will come to the point.

Speaker: Mr CAMERON THOMPSON
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The letter referred to an ex-gratia system of payment; it did not refer to the ex-gratia system of payment which has been now revealed by the government and presented. It is incorrect for the member for Oxley

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The member for Blair has made his personal explanation. Mr Ripoll- Mr Speaker, I rise on point of order: this is an abuse of the parliamentary process. While I am on my feet, can I ask you, Mr Speaker, that the member for Blair table the letter to which he is referring.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The member for Blair is not required to table a letter from which he is reading.

Speaker: Mr CAMERON THOMPSON
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I rise to refer to the fact that the letter was dated 21 January 2005. It does not refer to the ex-gratia system that was endorsed by the minister recently.

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Does the member for Fremantle claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I do, indeed, by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services in his speech to the House yesterday.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: In that speech the minister claimed that at a large rally in Western Australia last year I advocated that the price of petrol should be $2.50 and that that was ALP policy. As I told the House on a previous occasion when a similar allegation was made, firstly, I made no such recommendation but simply spoke at the launch of a policy document by the Sustainable Transport Action Coalition without endorsing its recommendations; secondly, it is not an ALP policy; and, thirdly, it was not a large rally but a small meeting. Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, this is a matter I wanted to raise on indulgence, because it is so serious. The Minister for Education, Science and Training has just tabled three pages that look to me to be papers written by individual students. The minister says that they are HSC papers, and looking at the papers I see that they are HSC papers from 2001. It is extremely serious that students' HSC papers are being tabled in the federal parliament. I would ask you to invesAutigate how the minister came to have access to these papers.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I will follow up that question and report back as appropriate. Education: Literacy

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, further to that matter, I would like you to examine the timing of this. When the Minister for Education, Science and Training got up and made his remarks here, he implied that the material was from an immediate examination-a current state of affairs-yet it appears that the documents he tabled are from 2001. That is from four years ago, not immediately. This would be a clear case of misleading the parliament. Given that the date is there, it would have to be said to be deliberately misleading. In those circumstances, of course, it would be a serious matter indeed. So both from that point of view and from the point of view of the matters raised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, this is a matter that needs to be pursued further.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the Leader of the Opposition. As I have indicated to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I will pursue the question that she raised. In relation the point raised by the Leader of the Opposition, I think he knows as well as anyone that there are forms of the House where such concerns would be better pursued. NA Howard Government

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for New England proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The necessity for the Government to treat Australian people with openness and frankness. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Trust in our parliamentary institutions is something that we all should value. There have been a number of occurrences in recent years which have meant people are starting to distrust their parliamentary institutions, and I think it is paramount that we all recognise that and try to do something about it. Whether it be in relation to issues like ‘chil- occurring. dren overboard', the Iraq war, the drought and the misrepresentations that occurred there, the free trade agreement, Telstra or climate change, the information that is transferred within this chamber and the other chamber is, from time to time, found later on not to be correct. That leads to a situation where the general populace do not trust the institution and do not trust the political process. Irrespective of who is in government, who is in opposition and who did what in the past, I think that is starting to erode the facilities of government itself. So I ask that we as members of parliament take this issue seto riously and try and do something about it. Just in recent weeks, and even today, the trust in the parliament was abused. The Deputy Prime Minister, for instance, said today: ‘There has been, in terms of the Telstra sale, a $3.1 billion investment in telecommunications infrastructure.' That is not correct. What has happened is that there has been a $1.1 billion investment in broadband and mobile services and a fund of $2 billion set aside, from which the interest will be used to invest in telecommunications infrastructure. That is not $3.1 billion. That is misleading the the public. When they find out the truth, the public's view will be that that they have been misled by the parliament. There have been a number of issues in relation to Telstra, such as the term ‘up to scratch'. A lot of people who vote assumed that in this case the National Party would abide by the terms on which it went to the last election-that it would not sell Telstra until it was ‘up to scratch', until all the recommendations of the Estens report were in place. That has not happened, and the National Party has voted for the full sale, the full privatisation, of Telstra. People are wondering why and how they can trust their parliamentarians when that sort of activity is Another phrase, ‘down the track', came into the parliament in the last week, used by Senator Minchin. Things will be right ‘down the track'. They are not up to scratch nowwe have been shown by the new CEO and others that there has been a massive underinvestment et cetera-but apparently, out of this package of $3.1 billion, which is really only $1.1 billion and the interest from $2 billion, things will be right ‘down the track'. When you look at that, though, you find that the interest from that $2 billion fund is $100 million-and those are the words of Mark Vaile, the Deputy Prime Minister, not mine. One hundred million dollars is less than the $125 million that the government has been providing annually over the last eight years-a $25 million reduction in expenditure on telecommunications infrastructure. And here we had again today a lack of openness when the Deputy Prime Minister, the Acting Prime Minister, said $3.1 billion is being invested. We have had the absurdity with the National Farmers Federation in the last few days. The farming community right across Australia, in all the surveys that have been done, have indicated that the service is not up to scratch, that they are opposed to the sale, that the Estens recommendations have not been fully implemented, that Sol Trujillo has said that there has been massive underinvestment and that particularly the underground infrastructure is in a mess-definitely not up to scratch. We saw the absurdity the other day of the President of the National Farmers Federation, Peter Corish, coming into this place and suddenly reversing the decision, and the outrage that has been expressed by the farming community about that. I questioned the President of the National Farmers Federation as to why that had happened. In a press release, the National Farmers Federation said that they had received a guarantee from the government that there would be pricing parity with telephone services and broadband. When questioned in the parliament yesterday, the Acting Prime Minister could not find where in the legislation that guarantee was delivered. In the Senate yesterday afternoon, Senator Conroy questioned the minister responsible, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, and she categorically said that there was no guarantee in terms of broadband services. That is in the Hansard. These are the sorts of things about which the community is being misled. There is no guarantee in the legislation; it was mentioned in a speech by the minister. I remember, when the goods and services tax was introduced, the National Party once again standing up and suggesting that, based on the price, there would be a degree of inequity in the application of the goods and services tax between city people and country people. Mr Fitzgibbon-And there is.

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: There is, as the member for Hunter said. The government put in place the Fuel Sales Grants Scheme to compensate for the inequity. Where is it now? It has gone, but the inequity has not gone. The application of the goods and services tax has not gone, but the Fuel Sales Grants Scheme has gone. The same brand of the same parliament that instituted it, for good reasons, has decided, ‘That's long enough; it can go,' and that is exactly what will happen with Telstra: ‘That's long enough; it can go.' It will drift away. I questioned the President of the National Farmers Federation as to why there was a reversal. Some of the state organisations were very angry about that decision. I made certain comments to the press that the President of the National Farmers Federation-it was no secret-was contemplating a political career and considering seats in the north of New South Wales and southern Queensland. He has not denied that. However, a strange person has come out of left field; the member for Gwydir has entered this debate. The member for Gwydir, in an article by Michael Thomson, was reported as saying: There is no deal for Peter Corish. There can be no deal. No-one is in a position to offer such a deal. The most powerful man in the National Party could not have arranged such a thingfor him. Even if he were to run, he's got to win preselection. It will be a very strong field, indeed. six people have indicated they want to run; it'll will be a battle royal. I did not mention the National Party to Michael Thomson when I talked about Peter Corish. I did not mention the seat of Gwydir. All I said was that it was no secret that this man was contemplating a political career in southern Queensland or northern New South Wales. That career may well be as an Independent in New England. The former Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party seems to know quite a bit more about this man that he has defended. When it comes to openness and frankness, they are the sorts of things that the community has a right to know. To add insult to injury, the President of the National Farmers Federation, Peter Corish, appeared in a radio program yesterday afternoon on 2AY in Albury, and I happened to be on the same program talking about Telstra. This was after Senator Joyce had made his decision, not by way of voting but by publicly announcing it. About an hour after that, Mr Corish said that the National Farmers Federation did not support the full sale of Telstra. I thought, ‘That's a bit absurd; that is not what he was saying the other day.' He then went on to say that the NFF did support the bills before the House. I have had involvement with the National Farmers Federation over many years. I was one of those who organised busloads of people to come down to Canberra to rally against former Prime Minister Hawke. Mr Snowdon-How could you?

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It was easy, and a lot of people came to rally against the indecencies of government in those days and to rally for honesty in government. To see the National Farmers Federation dragged to this all-time low and then purport to represent the farming community of Australia is quite disturbing. I have had phone call after phone call from Five or people who are involved in the associated organisations. I was on the general council of the New South Wales Farmers Association, and I was on the Grains Council of Australia. They have become puppets of government as well in respect of their attitude to ethanol. Some of these representative bodies have to make up their minds if they are to have any credibility in parliament, irrespective of who is in government. They have to start to represent the issues that their constituents believe in, and that is a broad reflection on the political process. We saw the farce in relation to free trade. The President of the National Farmers Association was involved in that well. There were concrete guarantees, when they left here, that sugar would be in, that there would be very strict rules in relation to open access to trade and that the beef industry would be entitled. A few words from Mark Vaile in the United States and that all fell apart. There is a whole range of issues on which we need more openness. We saw the development of national competition policy, and how that was underwritten, over the years. The two major parts of national competition policy on water reform were about a market being developed, which has partially been done, and property rights being recognised. It is 10 years on and they still have not been recognised. We have had all this palaver about how great it is with the bilaterals, the intergovernmental agreements et cetera. The people have been misled. Those people who have been sitting out there waiting for their property rights to be recognised when an environmental change occurs have been misled once again. There was Regional Partnerships-no wonder people are cynical about the political process. I hope the committee that is currently looking at that program makes recommendations to the Auditor-General, because I think there is a number of instances there where it is far greater than the traditional pork-barrelling that we would all accept to a certain degree-we might not agree with it on the day but it is part of the political process. But it seems to me that there may well be some corrupt activity in relation to where some of these funds have ended up and whether they have even been found. That might need a further inquiry. I have talked about the Fuel Sales Grants Scheme, ethanol, Iraq and other issues. In terms of the Telstra debate and political representation, I will be working to get people into this parliament who actually represent the people who they purport to represent. I will be part of it and I will be proud to be part of it. I encourage other members of parliament to stand up for the people they represent, irrespective of what side of parliament they are on or whether or not they are in a party. It is about time, particularly in relation to regional and country issues, that we started to stand up for those people. We have seen this classic example, an example greater than any other that I can remember, where country people have said to this parliament and all their parliamentarians by way of survey and carrier pigeon that they do not want Telstra sold. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I was expecting to hear something from the honourable member for New England, but what he said had nothing to do with the matter of public importance; it was more about getting the dirt off the honourable member for New England's liver. Quite frankly, that is all that we heard. If we want to talk about honesty and integrity in government and having people look up to politicians, I dare say that we have to start here. Most of it is generated from this particular chamber and from statements made here that are not entirely true. It does not just include this side of the House or that side of the House; it includes Independent members as well. This motion today is not so much about honesty or openness in government; it is more about relevance deprivation syndrome. Quite frankly, that is what it is all about. The honourable member for New England has been in parliament for a number of years: he was in the New South Wales parliament for a number of years-he was there when I was there-and he has been here for a number of years. Except for one term in New South Wales when he had the balance of power with the coalition government, he has achieved absolutely nothing in politics. He is bitter about that, and that is where most of these problems that he has at the present time come from. If people do not entirely accept the view of the member for New England, then of course there must be some ulterior motive, he thinks. We just heard a spray on the National Farmers Federation. I will say something about this Telstra debate because I think it is relevant to the whole process. There is no doubt in my mind that, as far as the people of Australia are concerned, the sooner we get some competition in this field the better. There have been many articles in the papers over the last few days showing how far behind we are in Australia compared to countries that have competition. Yet the honourable member for New England, the honourable member for Kennedy, the honourable member for Calare and those over on the opposition side would prefer to see us live in the Dark Ages. They do not want to see some of this competition. They then say: ‘Oh well, the government are not being honest. They are not being honest with the people.' As far as honesty is concerned, we are saying it exactly as it is. The honourable member for New England goes on about the services of Telstra, that it is not ‘up to scratch', as he puts it. If any electorate in New South Wales has benefited from the billion dollars that has been spent by our government over the last few years, it has been the electorate of New England. We still have the funds available to continue that. The member for New England is never honest enough to say that to the Australian people-that is the issue here today. When the member for New England had the balance of power in New South Wales, I remember one big statement he made over an issue in his electorate where he was looking for something from the government. He said that Greiner came along with a brown paper bag in his hand. That is what he said in New South Wales. It is a little bit duplicitous on the one hand to accuse people when on the other hand he has said similar things himself. Let us have a look at the openness of our government. I have heard those opposite and the Independents talk about the GST debate. I have also heard the cries of ‘never, ever' from over there about the Prime Minister saying at a previous time that he did not want to have a goods and services tax. But one thing I will say is that we went to an election with that as a policy. If anyone has ever fought a hard election, I can tell you that was a hard election because we were being open with the people about what was going to happen. The GST did not go to our government; it was for the benefit of Australia so that the state governments could get a growth tax to provide the services that they need in their states. It was nothing to do with us. We almost committed harakiri in the name of the country. If that is not honest, I do not know what honest is. It is the same when it comes to the words that are thrown around this chamber about ‘children overboard'. Have a look at the Senate inquiry. While at that particular time the Senate inquiry showed that the words may not have been used, children were thrown overboard only two or three days before. It was proven to be a policy of these people and what they were doing, yet in this parliament the Labor Party, in particular, try and distort the whole debate by just picking a few words out here and there instead of being absolutely honest about the whole debate. As I said, this is not the real reason behind this matter of public importance-the real reason has nothing to do with the words on the paper; it is to try and get the dirt off the liver of the member for New England. Mr Windsor-Tell us about the Fuel Sales Grant Scheme.

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: We will have a look at this fuel sales tax because it is something that the member for New England has been on about for a long time. It was not this government's policy; it was to get the GST through the Senate by a deal done with the Democrats. If the member for New England were patient, he might see something in the future, but he is never patient to see what might happen. That deal had to be done because the Democrats had this complicated that policy. I was not very happy about it at the time either, but if we wanted to get the legislation through there were a few things that we had to agree to. There were a few compromises that we had to make. We did not have the luxury of being an Independent, sitting back there being irrelevant and throwing your opinion around the place. When you are in government, you have to make some decisions and you sometimes have to make some compromises. But you make those decisions and those compromises in the interests of the country. This whole debate about Telstra shows a lack of vision by the Independents, in particular, and the Labor Party. There is no vision to see where we are going in the future with telecommunications. In fact, I suppose they could almost be classed as troglodytes, because the fact is that, if you want to see where we are going in the future, you will find that it is moving at a rapid rate, because we have competition. Only yesterday I noticed an article in the newspaper backing up what I said in my speech on Telstra the other day. It said that we can now give broadband across an electricity line. It is being rolled out in Tasmania. There is a second network-competition-and yet we are hearing this rubbish from the Independents that somehow or other the world is going to collapse. I can assure you that we are going to get better services, not because we have had any vision from those opposite but because people were prepared to sit down, have a look at the options and work through this. I also heard the member for New England mention climate change. I can only suspect that he was talking about the Kyoto protocol. I would be absolutely amazed and absolutely surprised if the member for New England were prepared to sell Australian jobs overseas. Mr Windsor-It's called fine particle emissions.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Order! The member for New England has had his turn.

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: We now have the idiot fringe over here talking about how ethanol will change that. Let me put it to you this way: if these fuels were competitive with oil at the present time, they would be in the marketplace. You hear all the ranting and the raving, but go and have a close look at the cost of these fuels. If they were competitive, they would be in the marketplace. I have heard the member for Kennedy before on ethanol and sugar. Let me say this to you, Mr Speaker: I will not be growing sugar for ethanol because you cannot make enough money out of it. That is just an absolutely nonsensical argument. With regard to the Kyoto protocol, obviously the member for New England is prepared to say, ‘We'll cut back on all our emissions, destroy our opportunities to develop and destroy our jobs in this country so that we can let undeveloped countries take over all those jobs and all those opportunities.' I do not think that is fair. The government's policy to reduce emissions overall and to give some encouragement for world's best technology in underdeveloped countries is the right one. Have we been dishonest about that? We have been quite open about it; we have told everyone exactly where we stand on that. So I think that that particular position is absolute nonsense. We hear a lot about these issues but I have yet to hear one word that I could believeand I did not hear it in this debate-that showed where this government had not been completely honest with the Australian people. The issues here are the fudging of the edges. I suppose that is politics, but to make the claim that someone has been deliberately dishonest is a dishonest statement. Mr Windsor-Where are the property rights for water?

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for New England wants to have a second debate here, apparently, because he does not like being told a different story and to hear another opinion. We had the situation in which he made all sorts of allegations about the grants to Regional Partnerships, but when it was asked that they be backed up in the Senate they were not backed up at all. Mr Windsor interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for New England was heard in silence.

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: If you have a close look at these grants, you will see that they are right across the board and not just in government seats. If you want to talk about rural Australia, you must ask: who represents rural Australia? It is the government members who represent rural Australia, so, naturally, there are going to be grants in seats in rural Australia, more government members will be involved than opposition members; they represent Sydney and Melbourne. Obviously that is going to happen. But then you make the claim that something is dishonest about this. Is it any wonder that people have concerns about it when the member for New England is out there throwing the mud around? Obviously people will start to believe some of this. I think it was Goebbels who once said, ‘Tell them often enough and they'll believe it,' and that is certainly the attitude that has been adopted. I would reject completely the allegations that have been made against the government in this debate, because, quite frankly, I have never served under a government that has been so open to the Australian people. We have gone to elections making it very clear where we stood. The member for New England talked about Iraq. If you want to go back to where the Iraq situation all started, the United Nations believed, Mr Butler believed and the British and Americans believed that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. We are all very wise in hindsight when we start to throw things around, but, at the time, the world believed that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. He was offered the chance of having inspectors in there and he refused. But now we have these wonderful people who, in hindsight, say, ‘You were wrong.' Hindsight is great, isn't it? But where were they leading? Where were they with their ideas? All they can do is sit back and snipe. That is their only ambition, and that is their only use in life-to sit back and snipe. The member for New England has been doing it now for a number of years. His absolute obsession with some of these things has to be seen to be believed. Yes, he missed if out on preselection for The Nationals. He stood as an Independent and won the seatcongratulations-but, since then, he has been bitter. That is where the whole thing comes from-the whole attack and all the issues. If something is going to be put up by the government, especially by The Nationals, he will oppose it; he will do anything to undermine it. We have heard it today. He wants to stand members in seats-that is not new. He has been out there before, standing Independent members in seats, but they have not won. I think that one or two seats went to Independents in certain areas, but then they came back again. That issue has been out there for a long time. I saw in the paper this morning that the member for New England was gloating and saying, ‘This is the end of The Nationals.' Let me tell the member for New England: as people realise that the policies that have been put in place are going to benefit those in country areas and as people realise what not just The Nationals but Liberal backbenchers from the country areas fought for in Telstra-to see that services in those nonprofitable areas were protected-they will understand. We will continue to roll out those services. They will also see the competition that is going to come into the marketplace. They will see that the prediction of doom and gloom by the member for New England and others was wrong. I have to say to you, Mr Speaker, that they will be grateful, because at the present time families in Australia are saving $750 a year because of the changes that have come into place in telecommunications, and they will save more in the future. Those in the isolated areas that are served by the member for Kennedy, for instance, now get subsidised satellite, and they have never had a better service. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I agree with the previous speaker, the member for Page, in saying that services from Telstra are good-well, I am not saying that they are good; I should say that they are acceptable. It has never been my position to condemn the services from Telstra. But if they are acceptable then why are you selling Telstra? If something is not broken, why do you want to fix it? Like me, the honourable member for Page has been a long-serving minister in a government. My policy was always: if it ain't broke, don't fix it, because we have enough broken things out there that do need fixing. I admire the member for Page in many ways, as I have said in this House on many occasions, but I cannot resile from my duty to point out to the House the statement by the government that they are going to provide $3,000 million to meet the requirements of rural Australia. I can skite; it is open get out there and skite, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, because, with all due respect, in sharp contrast to what you just said previously-that we have achieved nothing-if we were not here, if I had been beaten at the last election or the election before last or if the honourable member for New England were not here, we would not have lobbied the senators, and Telstra would have been sold the last time the government wanted to sell it. It would have been sold and there would not have been the $3,000 million that you people are claiming. I will come back to the $3,000 million, because we are talking about truthfulness, openness and honesty here. According to Telstra Country Wide, last year they put $231 million into new services. According to government papers, there was $280 million put into Networking the Nation and there was a further $163 million spent this year by Telstra Country Wide. If you add those up, you get a figure of $700 million. If Telstra had been sold, there would have been no $700 million there-and it would have been sold if we had not lobbied the Independent and small party senators. Three of them had made statements which at best were equivocal and, at worse, certainly indicated that they were going to vote for the sale of Telstra. That was until we did the heavy lobbying. I do not want to or have time to go into the detail, but it would have been gone. If you people are standing here today skiting about securing the $3,000 million, you should remember that there would have been no $3,000 million. It would have been sold three years ago. So if there is anyone to be thanked for this, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, by your own arguments it is the three gentlemen, the three amigos, sitting in this part of the House. Let me move on. Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, you said that we were ineffective. to me to The honourable member for New England and I secured money before the last election campaign which would make maidens blush. If they had been National Party seats, they would have got considerably less. They would have got the same as all the other National Party seats. But, because Mr Anderson, the then Deputy Prime Minister, wanted to indulge his own personal hatreds and vitriol, largesse was poured into our electorates like we had never seen before. But if we had just held up our hands and voted with the government-‘Gofer, send a rubber stamp and a photograph to this place'-then there would have been none of the largesse pouring in before the last election. I most certainly thank the government for the $227 million they poured into Kennedy in discretionary funds on the eve of the last election. I am not in a position to disclose what happened in the banana industry, but suffice to say that the imported bananas are not in Australia at the present moment. We still live in fear and terror that they are going to come in, but that was put off because of my actions, and I do not resile from saying that or apologise to anyone for saying it. The beef quotas came out and they were enormously detrimental to the grinding beef market of Australia. They helped the plate beef market, but they were dreadful for us. Again, I cannot outline what actions I took, but suffice to say that the quota arrangements were changed. Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, you are a very skilled person who knows a very great deal about the sugar industry, but you are not up to speed on this. With regard to the Brazilian ethanol program, the document I hold was produced by the Brazilian government and Unica-which you would be familiar with-and is to be presented at a Queensland seminar on ethanol. Page 9 says that, regarding the cane sector in Brazil, ‘Ethanol makes gasoline cheaper. There is no pure gasoline in the Brazilian market today.' There is E25 at US90c; and E100, which is pure ethanol, at US50c a litre. Working that back into Australian currency, the good people we have in the library tell me that it works out to 66c a litre. I am sorry, but the figure 76c a litre. When you add 12c a litre, which the government is applying in tax on ethanol-it is the only government in the world to apply a tax on ethanol-it comes out to 78c a litre. Then if you apply the excise regime on petrol it comes out to 114c a litre. I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, but I have to tell you that it is 78c a litre. That is what we should be able to buy it at. There is a transport and retail margin, but that goes on both fuels: petrol and ethanol. The comparable figures, before the retail and transport margin goes in, are 78c and 114c. They are not my figures; they are the figures from Brazil that were presented in Cairns. There were members of the government present in Cairns, Townsville and also at the big international seminar that was held in Brisbane. I was quoting the ethanol production figures recently at 600 litres. In fact, in one of the papers that was presented, they were still on 600 litres. That was corrected by the Brazilians, as I was. The Brazilians said: ‘We are now getting 700 to 800 litres out of ethanol.' But even without that, I am simply quoting the figures that the Brazilian government has produced. If the three amigos are not here, then every time we deregulate something everyone in this place will be for it. Everyone in this place is a free marketeer. The government did not invent this; in fact, they were also-rans. There was hardly anything left to privatise by the time they came in; it was all done by the Labor government and the policies have not changed. But the only three people with different policies in this place are the three amigos. We do not believe in the policies of free markets. Labor have already established that they do; they were in government for 12, 13 or 15 yearswhatever it was-and they privatised and deregulated everything that they could lay in Australia is their hands on. This government took over what was left-deregulation of the dairy industry, for example. I do not accuse you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Your position was made very clear to everybody, and there were other people who agreed with you. But that was what the government did. I am ashamed to say that at that time. I was part of the government. I made a decision to no longer be part of the problem. Maybe I am not part of the solution, but I am most certainly no longer part of the problem. For those that are in government, I am sorry to tell you that you are part of the problem. I had a lot to do with fighting corruption in Queensland and the most serious ramifications that occurred in that state. I am very familiar with how these things work. The payouts that were made in the fishing industry bear very close scrutiny. I give warning that I am scrutinising those payouts. I am scrutinising where the money flowed and how it flowed.
