The people where the citrus canker outbreak occurred were foreign people. They had special arrangements with the government that have never been denied in the newspapers or in this place. The citrus canker came in and there was a $5,000 donation not to party funds, where it had to be made public, but to a research foundation. That is where all this money is laundered. All parties do that; I am not singling out the National Party. When you have been in politics for 32 years like I have, your antenna goes up when something is done with indecent haste, such as the sale of Telstra. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Thank you for the opportunity to speak on this matter of public importance. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know that I am a new member in this place. I have not quite one year of experience, and today is my first opportunity to speak on what we call in this building an MPI. The member for New England brought on the matter of public importance, namely: The necessity for the Government to treat the Australian people with openness and frankness. There is not one person here who could disagree with that statement. I say these words as the member for New England is leaving the room. That statement has been notoriously twisted and turned around. It shows that what underlies the member for New England's actions today is nothing short of hatred. I really mean that. It has been evident. You could see it on his face; you could hear it in his words; you could hear it in the timbre of his voice as he spoke. There were no interruptions from members listening to him-the chair, members on this side of the House or even those from the opposition side. But as the member for Page was taking the opportunity to rebut some of the statements made by the member for New England there was constant interjection, interruption and sniggering and the member for New England made further spurious claims. I bear the member for New England no ill will; I hardly know him. As a new member I have met him a few times; he seems okay, but when he strides into this chamber something quite different confronts everybody in this room. It is worth pointing out to people who may be in the gallery or listening on the broadcast that to raise a matter of public importance it is necessary, when given the opportunity, for the Speaker to identify at least eight members of parliament who stand with the person who is raising the MPI to support the fact that we should have the debate. So today, given the opportunity, eight members stood; in fact, all of the opposition were here right after question time and they all stood in their places. They supported the member for New England in raising this MPI. If it is a matter of public importance, you stand and agree that we should debate this for an hour or an hour and a half. They are all gone.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: That's not right; I'm here.

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Rankin has returned, but they all went. The member for New England has gone. He does not want to hear any more; he has had enough; he has had his say. He has raised the MPI, but he has gone. He does not want to hear any critique of what he has had to say.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This is full of substance, isn't it! Mr Griffin-If you haven't got 10 minutes, just sit down.

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I would like to be heard. Mr Griffin interjecting

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Bass has the call.

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for New England raised a scattergun of issues claiming that the government had been less that honest, less than open and less than frank. He scattergunned with ‘children overboard'; he threw in Telstra, Iraq and even climate change for good measure, and we still did not get to the bottom of what he meant. He said that these issues and others were starting to erode public confidence in this important institution-not just the government but the parliament. I would have to say that I share some understanding of how people feel, particularly when they watch or listen to question time. I am very aware of this. I hear it in my electorate when I am meeting people. They often mention this-that question time is like a bear pit. People are attacking each other, sometimes personally. Today we heard it from the would be health minister, the member for Lalor, when she was attacking the Acting Prime Minister for taking steps to show some compassion when one of his colleagues was in hospital. I accept that. I understand that question time can be a pretty angry time. It shows us at our worse; I would admit that. But at least it is democracy in action. At least the chair has the opportunity to shut down people who are acting inappropriately, to kick them out they do not accept a warning and to require people to withdraw when they make outrageous statements-such as the time when the chair had to send out the member for New England for what have been proven to be outrageous, unfair, unqualified, unsubstantiated claims of bribery against the then Deputy Prime Minister, the member for Gwydir. What a shame that was and what a disgrace. There is a real arrogance in the member for New England today lecturing people like me on this side-lecturing this chamberabout the need to be open, honest and frank. It is shockingly arrogant. It is also very hypocritical. When he was given the opportunity to make the same statements outside the parliament, he would not do it. He was not prepared to make his claims against John Anderson, the member for Gwydir, outside this chamber-without the protection of the soft green leather chairs and parliamentary privilege. He would not do it. Instead of taking personal responsibility for himself, being accountable for his own actions and explaining to his electorate why he is not even here half the time-and I include question time and voting in divisions in that-he lashes out. As I have said, he is a man filled with hatred and anger. That is a great disappointment to me and I know it is a great disappointment to people all over Australia who have been witness to it. What a shame that instead of taking responsibility for himself he has only one course of action-to enlist the support of the Labor Party in attacking the government. They leave him for dead. He is on his own. They have just used him today as a puppet. Even the member for Rankin has now gone. I hope he comes back. I would like to hear what he has to say. I will listen to him. It is very easy to accuse other people of corruption. That is terribly easy. It is very, if very easy to attribute an improper motive to another person. None of us is perfect. I know I am not. Like so many other people on both sides of the chamber, I appreciate the value of honesty. None of us meets the test all the time. True integrity is living what you believe, living it out-actually demonstrating it. Honesty is saying the truth. I would say that, to a degree, everybody has integrity and honesty. All of us have that. For example, we all tell the truth most of the time. A truly honest person is someone who tells the truth even when it hurts-when it is hard to tell the truth, when they know they have done something wrong and they should give account. That is an honest person. A person with integrity is a person who lives their beliefs when it hurts them, when it costs them. I am not seeing it today. I have not seen it in some of the Independents' actions in my 11 months as the member for Bass. Rather than criticising other people and making virtually criminal accusations against them, I suggest that the member for New England should take account of his own actions. He should recognise that the claims he has made in the past are really claims that can be put up against his own test of not being open, not being frank. He was not prepared to make claims against other people outside this chamber. I suggest that some of the other claims he has made today he would not be prepared to make outside the chamber. When the member for New England says that these actions of the government, which he has virtually made up, are starting to erode trust in government, he is partly right, but he is part of the problem. He is the one who is talking down the positive attributes of, frankly, probably Australia's most honest Prime Minister and his government. The member for Rankin looks as though he has just emptied his stomach over there behind his desk. But the reality is that he is filled with hatred against the Liberal Party in the same way the member for New England is filled with hatred against any member of the National Party. We have heard about the disappointments of the member for New England today. We have heard about that fateful day when he missed out on preselection and then wanted to run as an Independent. Today the member for Kennedy, instead of saying that it is a bribe when somebody negotiates a position with the government and that involves a package of reforms and improvements to infrastructure-rather than saying that, as an Independent he is now taking the credit for Networking the Nation. You cannot have it both ways. This government is an honest government. This government, like me, is not perfect. But do not go lecturing us on being open, frank and accountable to the Australian people when we have demonstrated that we will go to an election with a hard policy and then implement it-not like the Labor Party when it goes to an election with l-a-w law tax cuts and then after the election shuts them down.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: What about the Medicare safety net?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Order! The member for Rankin!

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I rest my case. Mr Griffin-What about core and noncore?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Order! The member for Bruce is also in trouble. The discussion has concluded. NA AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 2005 Report from Main Committee Bill returned from Main Committee without amendment; certified copy of the bill presented. Ordered that this bill be considered immediately. Bill agreed to. Third Reading

Speaker: Ms LEY
Title: DEFENCE LEGISLATION
text: Farrer-Parliamentary Secretary (Children and Youth Affairs)) (4.14 pm)-by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA Publications Committee

Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I present the report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are being placed on the table. Report-by leave-adopted. PROTECTION OF THE SEA (SHIPPING LEVY) AMENDMENT BILL 2005 Returned from the Senate Message received from the Senate returning the bill without amendment or request. NA (MEDICARE SAFETY-NETS) BILL 2005 Second Reading Debate resumed from 13 September, on motion by Mr Abbott: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: The continuation of the debate on the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005 gives me the opportunity to comment on the government's honesty. I did welcome the just completed debate on the matter of public importance about the necessity for the government to treat the Australian people with openness and frankness. The government has failed to do that in the nine long years in which it has ruled this country. The contribution to the matter of public importance from the previous speaker, the member for Bass, was astonishing, to say the least, when he declared that the Prime Minister must be the most honest Prime Minister this country has ever had. The member for Bass is a new member and he may not be fully aware of the document entitled Truth overboard: 27 Lies told by John Howard and counting. I will not go through all of those because

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Order! That has nothing to do Report with the bill before the House.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I do want to confine myself to the Medicare safety net legislation. In order to do that we will need to set some benchmarks in truth and honesty in government. The Medicare safety net legislation is a formalisation of the breaking of an election promise by this government-the breaking of a promise that it knew before the election that it could not keep but it did not have the honesty to take the Australian people into its confidence and tell them before the election that it would not be able to sustain the Medicare safety net because it was too financially expensive and costs were blowing out. I mentioned that we need to make these judgments against benchmarks set by leaders. That benchmark was set in respect of this government by the Prime Minister of Australia when he was opposition leader. He said on 25 August 1995: Truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable in national political life. The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and most particularly the health minister knew the truth before the last election. The truth was that the Medicare safety net was unsustainable. The department of finance had advised the finance minister of this fact and obviously that fact was shared with other ministers. Nevertheless, the government proceeded to spend $20 million of taxpayers' money assuring the Australian people that the Medicare safety net would remain intact in full. The Minister for Health and Ageing told the Australian people just before the last election, on 16 September: I absolutely guarantee that the safety net, government has put it into operation, will continue-I absolutely guarantee it. He said in another interview 10 days before that: That is an absolutely rock solid, iron-clad commitment. We have just had a debate about truth and honesty in government. When the minister was making those statements he was aware that the cost of the Medicare safety net was blowing out and yet he continued to say that this was a promise that would be kept after the election. The government knew that it could not keep that promise; nevertheless, it continued to reassure the Australian people that it would be kept. During question time the same minister unloaded another bucket of vitriol in the Australian parliament, using harsh language but most importantly conveying to the Australian people his hatred and his bitterness. This is not a great day for the Australian Labor Party with the release of the Latham diaries-we know that. Mr Latham has left this parliament a very bitter and disappointed man. But we have in this parliament still a very bitter and disappointed man, and that man is the minister for health. The minister for health is a shadow of his former self-a shell of a man. I remember when I first became a member of parliament in 1998 and the now minister for health had been promoted to a junior portfolio. He used to lumber from the end of the front-bench to the microphone and, to show that he was a really tough guy, he would lay into the Labor Party or anyone else with his vitriol. This man has continued to do that right up to this day, in question time today. He is an embarrassment to the Australian parliament. He is a very bitter and disappointed man. The minister for health should himself consider his position in the Australian paras the liament and consider whether he has any further worthwhile contribution to make to public policy formulation in this country. We are debating a piece of legislation that formalises the breaking of a promise by the Howard government, the breaking of a promise by the minister for health and the breaking of an assurance that he would absolutely guarantee this as a rock solid commitment. But he is completely unabashed. There seems to be no embarrassment on the part of this minister to then get up in question time today as though he were some sort of great orator and great contributor to the parliamentary debates in our great country. He is not. He is a very bitter and disappointed man. His ambitions have been thwarted by none other than himself, because he has proven time and time again that he is a stranger to the truthas formalised in this Medicare safety net legislation. As I mentioned previously, the word ‘absolutely' comes out of the mouth of the health minister with monotonous regularity. When the word ‘absolutely' comes out in response to a question, particularly from the health minister, you need to be suspicious that in fact he is saying exactly the opposite. Where do I get the evidence for that? I get the evidence for that in a Four Corners interview of 1998, when he was asked about financial backing for Terry Sharples. The reporter's question was: So there was never any question of any party or other funds from any other source being offered to Terry Sharples? The minister answered: Absolutely not, absolutely not ...

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Order! It is hard to see how the member for Rankin could tie that back to the bill.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I am going to the health minister's credibility and capacity to tell the truth. The fact is that his incapacity to tell the truth is formalised here, today, in a piece of legislation that this parliament will be voting on. This piece of legislation declares that the minister's commitments-given as an ironclad promise with the use of the word ‘absolutely'-have today been broken. The government announced before the election that it would sustain this Medicare safety net, even though it knew before the election that it would not be able to do so. It put in $20 million of taxpayers' funds to assure the Australian people that the Medicare safety net would be retained in full. Mrs Draper- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I ask that you direct the member to keep his comments on the bill.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I have already done that, member for Makin.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: If the member for Makin had been listening, she would know that I was talking about $20 million of taxpayers' funds being used to perpetrate what the Australian government and the health minister knew to be untrue: that the Medicare safety net would be retained in full. If the member were to check the Notice Paper, she would know that the debate here in the parliament this afternoon is on the Medicare safety net legislation. I trust that, following the closing of my remarks, she will make some sort of a contribution to this debate. The fact is that the government did not tell the truth. Against the benchmark set by the Prime Minister of Australia that: ... truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable in national political life ... This parliament ought to condemn the health minister for his wilful incapacity to tell the truth. That is what has happened here today-and, in making some sort of assessment of this health minister, it is not the only time. Members of parliament may well recall a recent interview in relation to health policy that occurred on Lateline on 30 September last year. The transcript of that interview reads as follows: TONY JONES: Tony Abbott on another matter, have you met Archbishop Pell during the election campaign? TONY ABBOTT: Not that I can recall. TONY JONES: Not that you can recall, because we believe that you've had at least one meeting with him quite recently? You don't recall that? TONY ABBOTT: Well, when? Where? TONY JONES: At the presbytery in Sydney. TONY ABBOTT: Ah, actually now that you do mention it, I did meet with Cardinal Pell. So what? Why shouldn't I meet with Cardinal Pell? It was only when the health minister realised that Tony Jones of Lateline had details not only of the time of the meeting but also the venue of the meeting that the health minister realised that he would have to tell the truth. But if the health minister could have gotten away with not telling the truth, as he had attempted to, he would have. If the details had not been known to the ABC, the health minister yet again would not have told the truth. Here he is in parliament today in question time, unloading his bucket of bile in the Australian parliament because he has nothing to contribute to health policy. This is a man who presides over a health budget in excess of $30,000 million, yet he spends most of his waking hours thinking of language that he can pour out of his mouth in getting stuck into the Labor Party, while displaying to the Australian people that he is not fit to be a member of this parliament. There is one bitter and disappointed man who has left this parliament; another bitter and disappointed man ought to leave it as quickly as possible. We will do everything that we possibly can to ensure that the minister for health leaves this parliament; it is time. As was evidenced in this debate on a matter of public importance to raise the standardMrs Draper- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I fail to see how any of the honourable member's remarks relate in any way to the bill that is under discussion.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: The member for Rankin is in order.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will just use my last 30 seconds to explain to the member for Makin that the truth has a value-and the truth and a promise in this legislation is being broken. When this bill passes the House, this legislation will formalise the breaking of a promise by the health minister-and he should be condemned for it. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I rise to oppose the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005. It is interesting that we are speaking on this piece of legislation on a day when we have discussed a matter of public importance relating to the necessity for government to treat the Australian people with openness and frankness. This bill's purpose is to reduce the annual thresholds above which benefits under the extended Medicare safety net are payable. From 1 January 2006, the thresholds will increase from $306.90 to $500 for concession card holders and other low-income families, and from $716.10 to $1,000 for all other families and individuals. In debating this legislation, I wish to make three points. One is the fact that this is the legislation broken election promise by the Howard government. The second matter I want to discuss is the inequitable nature of the Medicare safety net. The third is that this piece of legislation and the Medicare safety net are other aspects of the government's health care program that lead to this mish-mash we have seen in the development of health policies by this government. In the short time that I have tonight, I want to go to the point of equity, because it is very interesting to look at where the benefit from this measure is going. From the latest figures available for the federal electorates in Victoria, each of the electorates of Kooyong, Goldstein and Higgins gains over $500,000 because of this policy: $560,000 to Kooyong, $529,000 to Goldstein and $523,000 to Higgins. If we look at Indi, it is $203,000. If we look at the seat of Scullin, it is $185,000. Mr Speaker, if we look at Wannon, it is $108,000. On equity grounds, how could it be said that an electorate like Wannon, in health policy, should gain around half a million dollars less in a quarter than electorates like Kooyong, Goldstein and Higgins? That is one of the problems with this overall piece of policy. The fact that this represents a broken election promise is an issue that also needs to be developed. NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being 4.30 pm, I propose the question: That the House do now adjourn. Indi Electorate

Speaker: Ms PANOPOULOS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise to comment on recent events in my electorate that deserve to be placed on the record in this place. Last weekend Wangaratta Aerodrome played host to a very significant event commemorating our returned service men and women. The Benalla campus of the Goulburn Ovens Institute of TAFE organised of a a successful Pacific flyers reunion to complement recent commemorations of the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific Day. The day included a flyover of historic aircraft, displays of fighter aircraft, a display of historic military vehicles and a tour of the museum precinct and the aircraft restoration facility. I want to thank Adrian Vaughan and his organising team from the Benalla TAFE, who spent many months organising this event. It was part of a documentary by the TAFE's multimedia students called On a Wing and a Prayer on the restoration of war planes. Over 1,000 people attended in blustery and wet conditions, including many veterans who came from far-off places. A particular highlight was the flight of a lovingly restored P40 Kittyhawk fighter-bomber which was last in operation in Papua New Guinea 60 years ago. It was back in the air last weekend at Wangaratta Aerodrome and was reunited with its former pilot, Robert Warren, who came from his home town of Tulsa in Oklahoma to be in Wangaratta for this historic event. Mr Warren was delighted at the restoration work carried out on the plane by Wangaratta's own Precision Aerospace Productions. But residents heard the loudest roar when they played host to an F18 Hornet flyover. At this point, I want to place on the record my thanks and appreciation to Senator Robert Hill, the Minister for Defence. At the last minute, when it looked like the flyover would not be able to take place owing to an absence of pavement concessions and indemnity insurance, the organisers approached my office and I swiftly took up the matter with the minister's office. Once these outstanding issues were addressed, the minister gave his approval on Friday afternoon for this historic flyover. I thank him and his office for doing everything possible to ensure that this very welcome and much anticipated community event went ahead. Former Wangaratta resident Shawn Mathews flew the Hornet from the base in Williamtown. Another event of note in the north-east last weekend was the annual staging of the Three Choirs Festival. This is a yearly event where the three pre-eminent choirs in the region-the Wangaratta Choristers, the Beechworth Singers and the Murray Conservatorium Choir-collaborate to deliver a series of concerts to audiences in our region. This year's feature work was the rarely heard Beethoven Mass in C. Beethoven is not particularly renowned for his sacred music compositions, but the Mass in C is a delight for listeners. Unfortunately, I was unable to attend the concerts last weekend, but I am told that the concerts in Yarrawonga, Wodonga and Wangaratta were a great success. Another aspect of the concert was the performance of a work by one of my constituents, local Wodonga resident Bohdan Krowicky. His piece ‘Thou and I' is a hauntingly evocative composition, with the text taken from a poem by the 13th century mystic Rumi. All credit goes to my constituent Mr Krowicky for having his own composition performed publicly. We can often forget the achievements of our musicians, artists and composers, particularly in rural and regional areas, but it is important to give these home-grown works a performance whenever we can. I am informed that the crowds were a bit down in Yarrawonga on the Friday night but that the attendances at Wodonga and Wangaratta were excellent and the crowds were definitely treated to quality performances by our local musicians. Thanks go to Ben Wilson, director of the Wangaratta Choristers, Margaret Phillips, director of the Beechworth Singers, and Michael Halsey, director of the Murray Conservatorium Choir, who prepared the respective choirs excellently for this event. Events such as this show that the arts and in particular musical performance are respected and encouraged in rural and regional Australia. We should work towards continuing to develop regional arts practice and the role of the arts in sustaining and fying our regional communities. Gaza Strip  year, 2005, has been an important year for both the state of Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Mahmoud Abbas was elected President of the Palestinian Authority, and Prime Minister Sharon and President Abbas declared a cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. In February the Knesset voted 59 to 40 to approve the disengagement implementation law, an act of parliament that would see more than 8,000 Israeli settlers in Gaza evacuated and the resultant vacant land given back to the Palestinian people. It must be said that Israel's decision to withdraw from Gaza has been controversial. Not many people would dispute that. Many within Israel itself were not happy with Prime Minister Sharon's decision but Mr Sharon, to his credit, persevered until this week, when the parliament formally recognised Israel's withdrawal from Gaza. The conclusion of an Israeli withdrawal from Gaza is a significant step towards an overall peace settlement in the Middle East and should be welcomed by all Australians. As Chief Opposition Whip, I take this opportunity on behalf of the Labor Party to commend Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, the Israeli parliament and the Israeli people for taking this courageous step, which has clearly been a very traumatic and painful process for Israel. Whatever we may think of Israeli occupation of the Palestinian territories or of the settlement policies of the previthat ous Israeli governments, the decision to remove more than 8,000 settlers from Gaza and return the territory to Palestinian rule is a major advance towards a peaceful settlement, particularly since it was done unilaterally and without any guarantees of security. Labor now calls on both sides to follow up uni- the momentum created by this withdrawal by taking further concrete steps to keep the peace process moving. On the Palestinian side, this must include a crackdown on those groups responsible for terrorist attacks on Israel and an end to the incitement and encouragement of violence and hatred. On the Israeli side, there needs to be continuing disengagement from the West Bank and steps taken to allow the Palestinian Authority to assume full responsibility for Gaza, including its air space and coastline, in a manner consistent with Israel's legitimate security interests. So why is this relevant to the Australian parliament? Because we on our side of the chamber take a keen interest in the Middle East. Labor wears on its chest with pride its role in the creation of an Israeli state. It was, after all, the Chifley Labor government which, over 50 years ago, was amongst the first in the world to give political support to the idea of a Jewish state. Under Labor, Australia was the first country to vote in favour of the 1947 partition resolution. And, as President of the United Nations General Assembly, former Labor foreign minister Dr Evatt played a key role in the founding of Israel in 1948. For the past 50 years Labor has never taken a backward step in advocating practical solutions to the long-running IsraelPalestine conflict. In recent years Labor has repeatedly urged both Israel and Palestine to engage on the road map to peace. We believe, despite some setbacks along the way, the road map offers the strongest possibility of a sustainable and robust peace between Israelis and Palestinians. Our policy is based on the right of the state of Israel to exist within secure boundaries. We do not back away from that. We vest our hope in a two-state solution involving the creation separate Palestinian state behind secure boundaries. A lasting settlement between the Palestinian and Israeli peoples is the only way forward. No-one should pretend that the road map to peace is an easy path. It is not. But gress is being made. The withdrawal from Gaza is another step forward. To ignore that fact is ignorant. Australia should do whatever it can in the coming months to encourage both sides to maintain the momentum created by Israel's decision to withdraw from Gaza. It is true that the honourable member for Fowler, who is always passionate about the causes she embraces, used some words in a speech which caused offence, but she withdrew them today after question time and I admire the honourable member for Fowler for her courage in doing so. Gold Coast Cruise Ship Terminal

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise today to express on behalf of my constituents and many residents of the Gold Coast our disgust at the betrayal by the Beattie Labor government of residents who live in my electorate and who live within the confines of Gold Coast City. At 11 am this morning the Beattie state Labor government ended the charade they had been carrying on with for a matter of months about what they would be doing with the cruise ship terminal on the Gold Coast. At 11 am this morning, Anna Bligh, the Deputy Premier and state Labor Minister for State Development, announced to the assembled media throng that the Beattie Labor government would be pushing ahead with the proposal to build a cruise ship terminal. Those on the Gold Coast who have been following this debate closely for some time would know that I have thought for some months-and, indeed, I had heard whispers for some months-that the Beattie state Laof a bor government had in fact passed through their cabinet last December the decision to push forward with a cruise ship terminal, despite the fact that it is very clear that many residents of Main Beach, Surfers Paradise and more broadly were opposed to the idea pro- of a cruise ship terminal on the Spit. Questions need to be asked. Why is the state Labor government undertaking this path? Why is the state Labor government turning up its nose at the residents of Main Beach? Why is the state Labor government turning its back on the residents of Surfers Paradise and imposing this cruise ship terminal in an area where nobody wants it to be built? The reason is that it is a knee-jerk political reaction from a very scared state Labor government to try to save backsides and to ensure the political survival of the state member for Southport, Peter Lawlor, and the state member for Broadwater, Peta-Kaye Croft. In this particular instance, what is very clear is that a deal has been done by the state Labor government in the context of a cruise ship terminal. In particular, the state Labor government has pushed forward with three key proposals as part of the development of a cruise ship terminal. So for many months now we have seen the state Labor government talking about the fact that it says a cruise ship terminal is good for the Gold Coast. Indeed, I support that notion, as does my colleague the state Liberal member for Surfers Paradise, John-Paul Langbroek. Dr Langbroek and I have been saying that we support a cruise ship terminal, but we reject entirely the notion that a cruise ship terminal should be built on the end of the Spit. We reject entirely that a cruise ship terminal should be built in crown parkland in one of the last remaining vegetation areas on the Gold Coast. We reject entirely that a cruise ship terminal should be built for the political convenience of two state Labor MPs and for the political convenience of the Premier, Peter Beattie. But I will tell you the reason why the state Labor government is insisting that a cruise ship terminal be built on the Spit. The reason is that it is part of a deal that has been done with the developers to redevelop the western side of the Spit. That has been the key behind this decision from the very outset. The reality is that the state Labor government has made an arrangement that the consortium that will build the cruise ship terminal, a loss-making venture, will do so on the basis that they have the opportunity to redevelop the western side of the Broadwater. Some 7½ hectares will be redeveloped into hotels, units and residential and commercial buildings because the state Labor government wants the millions of dollars of leasing rental that will flow to it by redeveloping that 7½ hectares. More importantly, the state Labor government also intends to facilitate this dodgy deal to have the sea scouts, the naval cadets and the water police move from their current location on the western side of the Spit and be incorporated into the development that is going to take place in this green area. The state Liberal member for Surfers Paradise, John-Paul Langbroek, and I object to this because we have seen the federal government invest millions of dollars through Green Corps projects and Work for the Dole projects to revegetate the Spit. We object to because the Beattie state Labor government has neglected public consultation in order to push this deal through. More importantly, we reject this deal because the Beattie Labor government has done this deal without being honest with the people of the Gold Coast. Today is a very bleak day for the residents of Main Beach and Surfers Paradise. It is a day when the Beattie Labor government has compounded its dishonesty, not only over the state health sector but also on this issue. (Time expired) West Papua

Speaker: Mr GARRETT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise to speak on the matter of West Papua. The Australian Labor Party has a long and proud record on human rights, and it is an area of real interest to me as a member of this parliament. That strong stance is set out in considerable detail in the ALP platform, which explicitly states: Labor considers the promotion of universal human rights to be a core foreign policy objective that cannot be traded off against other diplomatic and economic goals. Respect for human rights-the dignity and welfare of our fellow humans-is naturally our first and most immediate response to reports of human rights abuses. However, Labor also believes that respect for human rights is an important consideration in international relations. Respect for human rights contributes to domestic peace and stability and economic prosperity. This in turn contributes to the maintenance of international security. In this regard, I have been greatly concerned, as others have, by reports from church groups and human rights organisations about incidents of police and military brutality in the Indonesian province of West Papua. Most disturbing are the reports of the Indonesian army's involvement in the murder of Papuan independence leader Theys it Eluay in 2001. In particular, I draw the attention of the House to a report that was submitted to the UN Economic and Social Council on 9 March this year by Franciscans International on behalf of a number of respected and credible church groups, including the Catholic Institute for International Relations, the Protestant Church in Germany, Dominicans for Justice and Peace, and the World Council of Churches. That report noted that human rights abuses, including torture, arbitrary arrest and detention, and displacement, were continuing in Papua. There is no doubt that during the bad old days of the Suharto government the Papuan people were subjected to gross violations of their human rights. In addition to military brutality and political oppression, the province was neglected by Jakarta, with the Papuans lagging behind the rest of the country by virtually every standard of human development-infant mortality, literacy and life expectancy. The fall of the Suharto government and the subsequent election of President Wahid in 2000 gave rise to real optimism that a new era in Papua would unfold. It is important to acknowledge that there have been some positive developments, including the introduction of a special autonomy law granting Papuans political freedoms and autonomy. But the fact remains that we continue to receive disturbing reports of human rights abuses in Papua. Labor are very concerned about these reports. It is our view that a failure to address ongoing human rights concerns will only serve to undermine Indonesian authority in the province. Labor are also very disappointed at the failure to fully implement the law, which was passed by the Indonesian parliament in 2002. We have made our concerns clear to the Indonesian government and will continue to do so. The Leader of the Opposition and the shadow foreign minister, Kevin Rudd, took the opportunity provided by the recent visit to Australia by Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono to raise their concerns about the human rights situation in West Papua and the failure to implement the special autonomy law. Shadow minister Rudd made it clear when he said: ... when it comes to human rights abuses or gations of human rights abuses in Papua ... we have an expectation that the government in Jakarta will attend to those matters ... at a thorough level. Still, it is clear from reports recently made public, including Genocide in West Papua?-and the question mark following this title raises legitimate questions about whether it is the right term to use here; we do not think that it is-that the situation is of concern. That particular report, from the Centre for Conflict and Peace Studies, shows that the situation in West Papua continues to deteriorate and is very serious. Health conditions in some areas are very poor. The fact that special autonomy has not reached grassroots levels means there remain continuing infringements of people's rights. This is serious. So it is essential that this parliament provide encouragement to the Indonesian government to speedily advance those arrangements identified as necessary for the implementation of the special autonomy law. We have welcomed President Yudhoyono's success in negotiating a peace agreement in Aceh. His decision to grasp the opportunity provided in the wake of the tsunami to rebuild not just the bricks and mortar of the province but also civil society is acknowledged. It is now time for similar energies and commitment to be brought to bear for the people of West Papua. Member for Fowler

Speaker: Mr KEENAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I wish to place on record my concern over the comments made by the member for Fowler in this place on 13 September and 8 September this year and 2 December last year. It follows on from comments made earlier in this adjournment debate by the member for Chifley and from a question asked by the member for Casey to the Attorney-General in question time today. As the member for Stirling, I represent in this place a large Jewish allecommunity, a community that makes a large contribution to my electorate and to Western Australia as a whole. Indeed, I think the tribution that the community makes is out of proportion to the size of that community, which is not numerically large. I was reminded just this week that they can feel uniquely vulnerable, and as a community they have legitimate security needs. Also-and I think quite rightly-they are sensitive to any reference to the Holocaust. To come into this chamber and use terms like ‘concentration camp', ‘ghetto' and ‘ethnic cleansing' against Israel is enormously insensitive. No matter what your views on the conflict in the Middle East-and I am not disputing the right of the member for Fowler to hold a different view to mine on the conflict there-it is completely inappropriate for her to come into this chamber and to compare the mass extermination of six million people in concentration camps to events that are occurring in the Middle East at the present time. That is why using the language of the Holocaust against Israel causes such hurt to members of the Jewish community in Australia, some of whom actually survived the events she is now using to push a case about Middle Eastern politics. The member for Fowler needs to recognise these concerns in any future comments on this issue and she must apologise for going down this path in the first place. I well remember her earlier comments in December last year in this place eulogising Yassar Arafat-something I believe was very ill-advised given his well-known record as someone who used violence to achieve his political ends. For the parliament of a country that is one of the world's oldest democracies to be used to eulogise as a hero someone who ruled as dictator and used violence to achieve his goals, sometimes against his own people, is a very sad occurrence in the history of this place. I know that the member for Fowler has a conparticular view about Middle Eastern politics. As I said before, although I do not share this view I respect her right to hold it. But this tolerance does not extend to using this parliament to eulogise people of violence or to deeply offend Australian Jewry by using the language of the Holocaust in a wholly inappropriate way. While I am addressing this issue, I want to highlight some other comments made by the member for Fowler on 8 September in relation to Islamic fundamentalism. In my electorate of Stirling there is a large Muslim community. I have spent quite a bit of time at the two mosques in my electorate, and I have taken the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and the Attorney-General to meet with community leaders at different times. They have always been very clear with me that they reject Islamic extremism and the terrorism that emanates from that ideology. Sadly, though, the member for Fowler rejects this link and has used the parliament to outline her view that these terrorists are killing Westerners because of Western actions in the Muslim world. Last week she said: ... terrorists do not hate us for what we are; they hate us for what we are doing in their home countries. When we can appreciate that, we will be a lot closer to solving problems in Iraq and reducing the risk of terrorist attacks against Australians. But this cowardly government wants to hide behind another lie-the lie that Islamic fundamentalism is the root of terrorism. This goes well beyond the ALP's position on this issue, and I believe that this thinking skates very close to justifying the terrorists' repulsive actions. It also reflects terrorist propaganda. Islamic fundamentalists are killing Westerners because of who we are, not for any other reason. They despise us for our freedoms, and they despise us for our democracy. The Labor Party as a whole need to face up to this issue. Will they tolerate ple within their ranks who believe that somehow Western nations have brought this savage terrorism upon themselves, or will the opposition Leader show some ticker and repudiate-(Time expired) Minister for Health and Ageing The Nationals

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I am glad to announce that we are back doing the parliamentary fortnightly wrap. I have already congratulated the minister at the table, the Minister for Small Business and Tourism, for specifically wearing her Hollywood glam this morning. I think she has done very well indeed with the pearls, and it is obviously because she wanted to bring a sense of occasion to this evening! In the last parliamentary fortnight and ticularly in the last parliamentary week we have seen a week of guillotines. We saw the Telstra debate guillotined in this House on Monday. We saw it guillotined again in this House today. We saw it guillotined in an unprecedented fashion in the Senate. These were guillotines on a debate about the sale of the single biggest asset the Australian government owns and is ever likely to own-a week of guillotines. It seems to me remarkable that, in a week of guillotines, when debate has been gagged in this parliament, somehow the members opposite and particularly the Treasurer have taken to referring to me as Madame Defarge. I think there is a grand irony about that. Those are the lovers of the guillotine over there. They are the ones that have been cackling and laughing as the guillotine has come down on Telstra. But for sheer, breathtaking, amazing carry-on, we cannot go past the Minister for Health and Ageing this week in his capacity as Leader of the House, who has of course administered the guillotine twice in this peo- place to prevent members speaking but yesterday was-remarkably-raising a point of order with you, Mr Speaker, where he said: ... it would be almost an obscenity in a parliament dedicated to free speech if people were able to use personal explanations to gag debate in this Telstra place. The minister for health is the lover of debate on some occasions and the hater of debate on others. His views about free speech have to be seen as grandly inconsistent, because he was happy to guillotine opposition members this week, and guillotine them he did. The minister for health has certainly won the lack of consistency award, and he has also won the lack of taste and empathy award for the fortnight. In fact, his performance has gone from bad to worse. He started the week with parliamentary scandal about callous and insensitive remarks he made in parrelation to the matter involving Mr Brogden, and of course he has managed to end the week reinforcing his insensitivity. Nye Bevan-one of my Welsh forebearsfamously said, as his career progressed: ‘Real power always seemed to lie just beyond my reach.' I think for the minister for health it is respect that always seems to lie just beyond his reach, and he has certainly fallen very short of that benchmark today. What have we seen this fortnight? We have seen the once great National Party starting to emit a death rattle. We have seen the National Party at its worse-with the notable exception of the member for Riverina-as it sold out its constituency. With respect to the National Party, I think Alan Ramsey got it right a month ago when he interviewed a person he described as ‘one of the Prime Minister's junior colleagues' and as ‘a very jacked-off Liberal'. That Liberal had the following things to say about the National Party. Mr Speaker, I am sorry about the language, but I am quoting: The Nats are scum. They take everything and give nothing. They get elected on our coat-tails, they've got the worse ministers in the Government, they get the perks, the extra staff, the trips, the Prime Minister's ear, yet they never contribute. It's always about take, about self-interest. They're never part of the team. … … … Did you see Cobb's performance in question time today? He was hopeless. Just so bad. Is it any wonder Liberals are so resentful? And it goes on and on, ending up describing National Party members in the following terms: John Anderson was hopeless. Vaile isn't much better. Cobb is an embarrassment. So is Truss, the new deputy leader. An absolute embarrassment. MCGauran is a laughing stock. So why is there resentment from the Liberals? I mean, does one need to ask the question? You do not need to ask the question, because we have seen the National Party on display this week, famously without a backbone, except for the member for Riverina, and we certainly know that Senator Barnaby Joyce is still looking for his. In the parliamentary fortnight we have also seen, Sliding Doors style, a glimpse of what would happen with the alternative government. We have seen the Prime Minister away one week, we have seen the Treasurer away another week, and we would have to say that it has not been a pretty sight. Fran Bailey- Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I would have thought that it was in the interests of the Manager of Opposition Business to give a report on her own side rather than reflecting on others.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: There is no point of order.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I will just conclude by saying that the Treasurer has of course faced thousands and thousands of dorothy dixers in this place, and he is certainly going to face more as Treasurer. We know that he has had a bit of practice. He has been Treasurer for 3,475 days. As Jeff Kennett might well remark: how much is that in dog years? House adjourned at 5.00 pm

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Title: MAIN COMMITTEE
text: Australia tralia people are talking about the rising price way of life.
